title: Government urged to help with climate adaptation
article: There is much governments can do to help farmers adapt to climate change through agriculture research and promoting different farming practices, says Evan Fraser, Canada Research Chair in Global Food Security at the University of Guelph. It's crucial for governments to act because agrifood has the potential to boost its contribution to the national economy, he told the Senate agriculture committee which is studying the impact of climate change on farming. "There's a golden moment and a golden opportunity here for Canadian agriculture and that this opportunity was recognized by Dominic Barton in his report from the Advisory Council on Economic Growth earlier this year," he said. The government has a key role in making the golden moment reach its potential. He recommended the government "incentivize breeding programs, both for our crops and for our livestock that promote heat tolerance, drought tolerance or pest tolerance. ... For much of the 20th century, our breeding programs focused on simply boosting yields at the exclusion of traits such as resilience." "But I think by shifting government funding programs to support research into climate-resilient crops and livestock and then by engaging in public-private partnerships with input suppliers, we can provide farms with the genetic tools they need to adapt. "Similarly, we can also create incentives for farmers to use more agri-ecological principles that will help improve resilience as well," he said. "Creating incentives to encourage crop rotation or conservation practices help because these practices build up the organic matter in our soils, and this is important because organic matter acts like a sponge, trapping water when it's abundant and saving it for when it's needed." The committee should also focus on agriculture's potential to use technology to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions, he said. Digital technologies, "which include smart tractors that know where they are in the field and plant the right seed in the right place and give it the right amount of fertilizer with no waste, are sometimes called Agriculture 4.0." 'They give us the opportunity to produce more food with fewer greenhouse gas emissions, and since agriculture is responsible for a third of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, this is really important. "At the moment, however, Ag 4.0 is in its infancy, both in Canada and internationally," he said. "For instance, it requires huge amounts of data to be integrated. That smart tractor needs to take soil maps, needs to integrate it with Environment Canada weather station data and needs to take remote sensing data from our satellites and bring it all together. "At the moment, this sort of data integration isn't happening, and as a result, we as a global society as well as a country are not realizing the potential of these new technologies," he said. "I think this, however, represents an ideal opportunity for Canada to show leadership." Ottawa could help by "developing protocols pertaining to data sharing, cybersecurity, data ownership and data integration that would apply across the entire agrifood sector and make Canada a leader in developing and applying the technologies that will allow us to produce more food with fewer greenhouse gas emissions." The committee should also consider carefully the agriculture potential of Northern Canada as the climate warms, he said. "Our northern soils are very fragile and are huge reservoirs of carbon." "Some work I've been involved in suggests that if we start seriously cultivating northern soils, we will create huge new carbon emissions that will destroy Canada's ability to meet our Paris accord commitments." "This doesn't mean that agriculture can't happen; it means we have to be creative about it. "Maybe instead of thinking about wheat fields or soybean fields in the North, we think about extensive bison or caribou production that is then deliberately marketed to international discriminating markets," he said. Adaptive farming practices and expanded use of digital technology could help the agrifood sector "become more adaptable to climate change and extreme weather but also reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and build new export markets by demonstrating to our trading partners that our food is the most sustainably produced in the world, thereby establishing a brand Canada." "Similarly, I think we can develop secondary markets to sell climate-friendly agricultural technologies to our trading partners."

title: Linamar Corp to Acquire the MacDon Group of Companies, M&A Call - Final
article: Presentation OPERATOR: Good afternoon. My name is Amanda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the acquisition review conference call. (Operator Instructions) Thank you very much. I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Linda Hasenfratz. You may begin your conference, ma'am. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ, CEO AND NON-INDEPENDENT DIRECTOR, LINAMAR CORPORATION: Thank you very much. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us to review our acquisition announcement this afternoon. Joining me this afternoon are members of my executive team, Jim Jarrell, Mark Stoddart, Roger Fulton, Dale Schneider and some members of our corporate finance, marketing and legal teams. Okay. Just moving through our presentation this morning. I want to draw your attention to this statement regarding forward-looking statements we might make on this call. I'm not going to read it to you because I'm sure you can read it yourself, even though Roger's looking upset about that. So let's move on to the key messages around this acquisition. We are very excited to announce today what we see is a really important step in our growth and diversification strategy, the acquisition of MacDon, who is a global harvesting specialist headquartered in Winnipeg, Manitoba. We're excited about the deal from many different perspectives. It provides us diversification into an opportunistic market. It provides innovation as MacDon is considered an innovative market leader in all their products. Of course, it gives us growth both immediately and longer term as we grow the business globally, and we feel it's a financially attractive deal as well. So just to talk a little bit about each of those these points a little more. Clearly, we see that the opportunity enhancing our position as a global diversified manufacturer. We have talked a lot in the last couple of years about the fact that the agricultural food market is a key long-term growth market given the growing and developing global population out there, so we think lots of opportunity. Linamar has a long history of involvement in the agricultural market, as we'll show you shortly. And we like the idea, as you know, of diversifying beyond the automotive Powertrain/Driveline and access manufacturing we do today. As I mentioned, MacDon is an innovative market leader. In fact, they have #1 market share in each of their key products. They've got a real track record of technology and innovation leadership that we really like. As you know, that's a key element in which we run our business today, so we love the synergy there. We think there's significant opportunity to leverage their strength with Linamar's global manufacturing expertise and lean principles through employee engagement process. We think there is significant growth potential and upside opportunities, first of all, because the agricultural market is in the early stages of cyclical recovery. Secondly, we think there's a lot of opportunity to grow the business globally. A high percentage of sales today are in North America, so the global market is out there for us to expand into. And we think there's possibly some opportunities of synergies from a distribution perspective. And lastly, as I said, I feel it's a financially attractive deal. We think this is a strong, well-managed company with great financial performance and solid outlook. We think it was a fair price that we paid. It is immediately accretive to earnings and cash flow even before considering any synergies. And at the same time, it allows us to maintain our strong balance sheet, which is quite important to us. And we do expect to rapidly delever post the transaction. So just to review the transaction. It's also little bit more on the cost was $1.2 billion from which some transaction-related expenses that will be borne by the sellers will be deducted. The EBITDA multiple for the transaction was 7.8x last 12-month EBITDA, which compares well, we feel, with precedent transactions as well as public company trading comps of similar businesses. We see, as mentioned, high single-digit accretion right out of the gate on both EPS and cash flow. We have fully committed financing in place for the deal, which will leave us at about 1.7x net debt-to-EBITDA at close. And as noted, we do expect to rapidly delever back under 1x EBITDA within the next 18 to 24 months, which is fantastic. So just to recap a few details about MacDon. It was founded in 1949. It's headquartered in Winnipeg, Manitoba. They are selling around the world but as noted, high percentage of sales today in North America. They have several sales and product support offices around the world to support that global network. They have a fantastic dealer and distribution network from which they sell their product and a solid leadership team and a great base of employees. There's about 1,400 people that work with MacDon, more than 100 years of collective experience on the management team, which is great. Key products are rigid and flexible draper headers as well as self-propelled windrowers. I'll describe that a little more in a moment. They have several facilities, as noted, around the world. Most of them are sales and product support offices. All the manufacturing is happening in Winnipeg. Just hitting some of the key historical financials over the last 5 years. Sales have been in the range of $550 million to $650 million. EBITDA margins are typically in the range of 20% to 25%. Depreciation is pretty low, as is CapEx. So not dissimilar to our Skyjack access business. And last 12-month sales were roughly $600 million. So moving on to a better overview of the product portfolio. As I mentioned, the 2 key products are pictured up at the top of the screen. First, draper headers, both rigid and flexible. So these are harvesting units that attach to the front of a combine or a windrower, and they're used to harvest a variety of crops such as soybeans, wheat, oats, et cetera. MacDon sells these units directly to farmers for the most part through their distribution network. The next largest product is self-propelled windrowers, which are used to cut and lay crops in the fields like hay or other crops that need drying before picking up. Other products include pickups. So to go back and pick up that hay once you cut it and it's dried in the field and other hay products like auger headers and rotary disc headers. Of course, they also have a thriving aftermarket parts division, which is branded Westward Parts. You can see here MacDon's global organization. As I mentioned, all the manufacturing is actually in Winnipeg. They have 2 key R&D centers, one large center in Winnipeg and another in Wisconsin, and then several sales and product support facilities around the world, here in North America as well as Europe, Asia and South America. So just good global footprint to grow from. Of great value, of course, is MacDon's extensive North American distribution network, which you can see illustrated here. They have great relationships with their dealers, which have been very carefully developed over the last 30 years and have been a huge asset for them. The international market is, as you can see, a smaller chunk of the revenue today but we feel has huge growth opportunity in the future. Organizationally, the business is going to fall into our Linamar Agriculture group, which we created, as you recall, about a year ago. From a segmented financial perspective, it's going to fall under our Industrial segment, alongside Skyjack, whose business metrics are quite similar, as already described. So turning to the strategic rationale for the acquisition. I would boil it down to really 6 key things: first, clearly enhancing our position as a global diversified manufacturer. We like the idea of having a diverse markets but more avenues within which to grow the company. As noted, we have a long-standing history in the ag market, and we think it adds significant size and scale to our existing agricultural equipment platform. We love the idea that MacDon is an industry-leading business with great market share. So they have leading market share in several categories. They are #1, in fact, in FlexDrapers, in Combine Draper Headers and self-propelled windrowers, which is fantastic. They are certainly recognized to be a technology and innovation leader in terms of great technologies, great product quality and have a long history of innovation in the company. Their technology is supported by over 100 unique patents, with an additional more than 30 pending on a global basis and a strong technically -- technology-focused staff of over 100 people. We feel there is significant growth potential and upside opportunity in several -- from several perspectives. As noted, the opportunity to lever North American leadership with Linamar's global manufacturing is key. We think there's lots of opportunity to tap into those global markets where they are a player but not as big a player as they are in North America and opportunity to expand and enhance our -- both our agricultural and industrial product offerings and market reach on a global basis. The agricultural market, as I mentioned, is in the early stages of cyclical recovery. So it's a great time to step into the market and really take advantage of things starting to improve and gain some momentum. And finally, again, a financially attractive deal. We think it's a fair multiple. 7.8x is absolutely in line with the trading multiples we've seen for both precedent transactions and for companies -- similar companies in the industry. It's immediately accretive. There's some modest synergies that we will realize, and we do maintain that strong balance sheet, which I think is quite an important point and certainly has always been important to us. So with that, I'm going to turn it over to Jim to talk a little further about the diversification concept and how MacDon really helps with that goal. Jim? JIM JARRELL, PRESIDENT AND COO, LINAMAR CORPORATION: Thank you, Linda. Good afternoon, everybody, and it's great to be here today. And it's really a great opportunity for us to explain what we're doing. And really, I will say this is a culmination of a couple -- 3 years of research and study that we have been working on at Linamar in regards to finding the right partner for this product area. So we've really taken a lot of approach and analysis to this deal. Certainly, it's an excellent technology partner in this space. And I can also say based on our getting to know this company, they have a great workforce, great leadership and really a great legacy. And we've gotten to know this leadership group out there very well, very capable team. And the 4 anchor shareholders, the 4 brothers, have this long legacy of discs. And their blood -- their father, Joseph Allen MacDonald (sic) [Joseph Andrew MacDonald], basically founded and started the company and really had trained and helped grow this. So really a great legacy company and really fits in well with Linamar. Certainly, looking at sort of the global trends that we have been talking about probably for a few years with you, our shareholders, is obviously global population growth, which is nothing really new. But that's a big deal for the agricultural business, rapid technology evolution, a lot of things around AI, autonomous. And in the ag sector, this could all be about precision farming, which, of course, a company like MacDon is very aware of. Aging population is certainly another key around growth of people and need for more food, and of course, urbanization. And we've been talking about this Vision 2100 for some time now. And certainly, this was created in Linamar about 4 years ago. And I think with this actual deal transaction that we're doing, we're staying very true to this 2100 year plan. And of course, this is building the future in regards to transportation, of course, which is the mainstream for Linamar today; infrastructure, which is all around Skyjack; and industrial; and of course, Oros as well. And then food, here's our major play into this food sector with MacDon and the other sectors, which, of course, each have an eye out for the future. But obviously, nothing today on those. And then the other side, on the left, which is all about manufacturing, processing capabilities that Linamar is known for and constantly evolve in the company. Sort of why food and ag, I think, would be one of the key aspects that people would be thinking through. It's really an attractive demographic and really economic fundamentals. Really, there's a global food demand which will continue to grow, and the ag market is basically a large and very dynamic market today. And if you look at some of the comments like Linda said that were sort of coming out of the cycle and if you read around what John Deere and companies like that say the uptick looks like 5% to 10% in the ag and food and there's pent-up demand that obviously will be replenished as well. Other reason is Linamar's long history in the ag equipment sector. A lot of you won't know this, but Frank had bought the White Farm in the '80s and had run that. And then also, we produce combines for ag though under the name Western Combine. Of course, I think most of you know we acquired Oros in Hungary, which manufactures corn heads. And currently, we do corn headers and sunflower seeds in Hungary with distribution in North America through Harvestec and then in Europe under Oros. Last area of complementary product portfolio. I mean, this really extends the ag product portfolio that we have in the product lines and certainly, Linda highlighted this as well, starts to be able to share some technologies, geographies, technology through potential crossover distribution channels that obviously we'll have to factor in and think through as we develop our strategy for growth there. The long history. I mean, again, just highlighting this. During the 1980s, owned White Farm; basically during the '90s, produced combines, actually down on the left there, for Massey Ferguson; and then in that time frame, acquires Oros in Hungary, where we manufacture corn heads; and then currently, basically before this transaction, got product lines in corn headers and sunflower harvesting equipment under the brand names of Harvestec and Oros; and now today with this great announcement, have MacDon as our future catalyst that will really take us forward into the future. The complementary product lines, I think this is a pretty interesting slide here. When you look at Oros, Harvestec on the top there under the green harvesting, the checkmark is what we have without MacDon. And then adding in MacDon is a great product portfolio. Check the marks on drapers, pickups and rotary mower heads. And really, this combine business covers a wide crop range of harvesting product lines, as Linda mentioned, wheat, canola, beans, soybeans and other product lines like that as well. When you look at -- this is on basically a segmented basis, the Powertrain/Driveline, which is very familiar with on the left, at the top section, and then moving to the right top section now with Industrial adding really significant size. The Ag business there really taking us up to about 10% in that area on the ag sales. And at the bottom, you see the revenue base on the pie chart, standalone and pro forma on the sales revenue base and then moving over to the EBITDA standalone versus the pro forma. So really just some complementary growth and a really good focus on the growth side as well. With that, I'm going to hand it over to Mark. MARK STODDART, CTO, EVP OF SALES & MARKETING AND NON-INDEPENDENT DIRECTOR, LINAMAR CORPORATION: Thanks, Jim. Good afternoon, everyone. Just a little bit on the products. And as mentioned earlier, MacDon is an industry leader with the FlexDraper, they are #1 in North America; the Rigid Draper, they're also #1; and with the self-propelled windrowers in the mid-horsepower range, they are also #1. They are, as mentioned, an innovative leader. They have well over -- currently have well over 100 patents right now and another 30 some-odd patents that are pending. They have a total of around 110 dedicated product development people in the product engineering group. Looking at some of the innovations around some of the products. On the FlexDraper, one of the unique things about this product is the higher cutting speeds, that the design of header units of being flexible over the terrain of the soil allows for reduced seed losses. And also, the unit has a higher capacity to bring more of the crop into the combine. On the self-propelled windrowers, they are an industry leader in load speed as product travels on the roads to get from the various fields. And they do have some very unique technology that allows it to move fairly quickly on the roads. Very improved operator comfort and interface with the unit. On the hay products, they have market-leading in regards to the transport system on this unit, and they've recently improved the flow for crops and also the formation in the windrowers. As we talked about already, significant growth potential and upside opportunities for internal expansion. As we mentioned, MacDon is pretty focused around North America but does have a fair bit globally, obviously tapping into Linamar's existing manufacturing in Europe and in Asia. We're currently doing fabrication work in our Hungarian plant. So we've got some well-established operations that MacDon can benefit from. MacDon also has a global reach, and we talk a bit about that, but their dealers of over 1,400 dealers and sales of parts globally, which could again benefit for us. On the product line side, we continue to expand and see great opportunities with MacDon as they expand their product range and can look to see what we currently have in regards to our own product range. One of the big areas that we see some great opportunities for expansion is in the parts marketing. Back in 2012, they acquired Westward Parts Distribution, a very well-run operation, and we think could have some benefits for Skyjack. And then on the operation side, obviously Linamar is a leader in manufacturing. And one of the areas we see is incorporating our lean philosophies and working with the employees to make improvements. And we see that as a benefit for MacDon, and we see that there is definitely a lot in sharing technology and distribution networks for both the Ag and the Industrial side. And with that, I will -- oh, sorry, one more. As you've just seen -- just trying to hurry things up. As you've seen -- as many of you have seen, we have an outlook report. So we've adjusted it now to include the ag. And as mentioned earlier, we see really some good growth here in North America. The industry has been in a bit of a downturn for the last several years, but we've seen inventories get fairly depleted. And really throughout 2017, dealers have been starting to restock, and we see this momentum continue out through 2018. Likewise in Europe, we see some moderate growth; and Asia, flat. But again, as we mentioned, MacDon's largest area is North America. So we do see a lot of opportunities for growth. And with that, I'll turn it over to Dale. DALE SCHNEIDER, CFO, LINAMAR CORPORATION: Thanks, Mark. Good afternoon, everyone. Just to look at some of the financial numbers. As Linda mentioned, they do have a very strong EBITDA margin in the 20% to 25% range, which is much better than the peer group numbers you can see there in the 12% range. From a CapEx point of view, they are similar to Skyjack in that they are not a capital-intensive business and tend to be, like Skyjack, a good generator of cash flows. And as a result, you'll see high single-digit EPS and free cash flow accretion in the first 2 years. We do see some moderate synergies from a procurement point of view, leveraging the distribution networks, as Mark had mentioned. And looking at what we can do from an engineering side as well and also looking at it from a Skyjack distribution point of view, it could have some benefits to us as well. From a price point of view, we do think it is a fair deal. As Linda mentioned, the past 12 months EBITDA multiple is in the 7.8 range, and it is a little better than the median precedents and current trading multiples. So we think it was a very fair deal. Looking at it from a balance sheet point of view. As you know, Linamar has always maintained a very conservative balance sheet. We have, in the past, levered up for strategic reasons. And you've seen that in the past, where you see [presented] back in 2016, we levered up to get the ['16] transition business and we levered up in 2016 as well by the Montupet casting business and then have been working on quickly deleveraging those scenarios. And we see this modeling out very similarly. We'll lever up to 1.7x and we will delever rather rapidly over the next 18 to 24 months. A lot of people know that Linamar has had a very solid growth plan. We have a very high CAGR in both revenues and earnings. But I don't think everybody necessarily understands how much of that has been done through M&A in addition to the organic growth we've seen. So if you look at it from back in 2001 when we had about $1.2 billion in revenue, we are now at $7.1 billion. EBITDA has grown by almost $1 billion in the same time period, really being driven by a few -- from the M&A side from a few key acquisitions, going back to Skyjack in 2001. So we got really into some of the fabrication and assembly work we were doing with telehandlers. 2015, we bought our Forging businesses, mainly the Seissenschmidt forging group. In 2016, as we mentioned, we got into the Light Metal Casting through the acquisition of Montupet as they're one of the largest aluminum casters of sonar heads. And now once again, another large but a good acquisition with Montupet, we'll continue to drive that growth -- MacDon, sorry. If we look at it from a trading multiples point of view, Linamar trades -- if you look at enterprise value versus next year's EBITDA and from a price earnings point of view versus next year, we're in the 4.5 to 5 on enterprise value and around 7.8x on the price. If you look at it from a peer group point of view of just purely autos, we are slightly under that. If we look at it from an industrial point of view, so the Skyjack business, most of those trade in the double-digit enterprise value/EBITDA almost 11x and price earnings is almost 20x. So when you look at it from adding in the (inaudible) group who has an enterprise value/EBITDA in the 10x and the price to EPS in the 19x, we think this will track a much higher multiple for Linamar overall and drive more value to our shareholders. So just to summarize everything we talked about from a Linamar perspective, we believe this will help us enhance our entire global manufacturing business. We are adding an excellent company who has an industry-leading business. They are a technology and innovation leader, as we've talked about. We do see significant growth in the business, especially when you look at outside of North America. And we're buying at the right time where the ag market is just starting to recover. So there's also growth opportunities there (inaudible). And as I just went through, it's a financially attractive transaction. So those are my comments, and we'll open up to questions. Questions and Answers OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Mark Neville from Scotiabank. MARK NEVILLE, ANALYST, SCOTIABANK GLOBAL BANKING AND MARKETS, RESEARCH DIVISION: Just, I guess, several questions. First, can you just give sort of a sales breakdown by geography just to understand where they're selling this product? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. The majority is in North America. So we flipped through a slide that showed the breakdown of the distribution network. So that's well representative of the actual sales split between Europe, North America. And then there's a small slice there for the OEM -- that we sell to OEMs. So that piece is -- we're not splitting out geographically but it's a smaller chunk. So you can see on that pie chart about 75% North America distribution network and about 14% international. And then the 10% OEM is split out amongst that. MARK NEVILLE: At the North American business, is that primarily the U.S.? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: U.S. and Canada. DALE SCHNEIDER: It's split. It's split both. MARK NEVILLE: Okay, okay. I guess just in the international expansion, I guess that sounds like where the upside could come from. Would that require significant investments in facilities or manufacturing on your part? Or could you do that on your existing network or your existing footprint? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: We would do that in the existing footprint. I mean, obviously just like with Skyjack, we used the footprint here in Canada to serve most of our global markets. And once we get up to a significant level of sales outside of -- significant -- enough level of sales in some of these other regions, then we might consider local manufacturing. But that's a long, long, long ways away in terms of getting up to enough volume for that. MARK NEVILLE: Okay. And then I guess just in terms of -- and I get the diversification you talked about. But just any benefits that can be derived from combining this with your existing businesses? Can you maybe just touch on that? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. We definitely think that there's opportunity certainly in terms of our Agricultural business that already exist in Hungary. So we will certainly combine the 2 and look to find opportunities there. There could even be some opportunities with Skyjack and their business, particularly in Europe. JIM JARRELL: I think there's synergies on manufacturing and purchasing that drive really closely with Skyjack because they have a similar type of manufacturing processes. And certainly when you look at the branding and the distribution channels, obviously that's something we have to investigate. But there is a lot of distribution channels as well. And certainly, Skyjack, one of [the areas] for European telehandlers can we then embark on that globally as well. MARK NEVILLE: Okay. And then one last one. I mean, you touched on it, Dale, just on multiples and sort of where you're trading and where your comps are trading. I guess just arguably, now you're not really getting credit for the Skyjack business. Just wondering, you add an Ag business again. I appreciate it's a higher multiple business and it's probably a fair price. But again, if you're just sort of worried that again you don't get credit for it and the multiple stays low and just your thoughts on that. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Well, I mean, frankly, we think that sum of the part valuation is a better way to look at Linamar. I mean, we've long felt that way about our Industrial business and then only add to that. So I mean, clearly, these businesses have a lot of value. They've got great growth volume. Look at Skyjack, perfect example. We've grown it 6x what it was when we acquired it. And it creates an enormous amount of value. So totally agree, Skyjack, the multiples in that sector are a lot higher, in the 8 to 10x range. Same in the ag space. So we'd love to see you valuing those pieces of our business that way. OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Paige from Gabelli. MATTHEW T. PAIGE, RESEARCH ANALYST, G. RESEARCH, LLC: I guess maybe could you first start off by talking about how you found MacDon? And why are they selling? JIM JARRELL: Yes. We've known MacDon for several years. And as I mentioned at the beginning, we've done a lot of investigation in regards to product lines that would be complementary to what we do over at Oros, and they were also a customer to us as well. And so that's how we originally got to know them. And then when we created our Vision 2100, we really thought we would focus in on this area to add product line to our Ag business. So obviously, MacDon was the key one. And the reason they're selling is their father, Joseph Allen MacDonald (sic) [Joseph Andrew MacDonald ) who ran the company, had 4 sons, and the 4 sons are -- have been in the business and did an outstanding job and made a plan about 8 years ago to have succession. And they brought in a professional management group several years back, which are excellent, the guys I refer to, and have been looking at this divestiture on and off for a few years. And quite frankly, we've been talking to them as well. And the timing was right for both companies in the past 12 weeks to make that deal happen. MATTHEW T. PAIGE: Got it. And you also mentioned that the leadership of the company has been great in the past. Are there people in the management at MacDon that are staying with Linamar now? JIM JARRELL: Yes, absolutely. There is the key, Gary, who's the CEO, President. They've got the CFO. They've got [Jim], who's the marketing guy. They've got [John], the engineering. Yes, and they've got that whole leadership group that are staying. And quite frankly, we want them to stay. And so of course, from a succession perspective, we need to know who's in succession behind those folks. But yes, that's our intention. MATTHEW T. PAIGE: Got it. And from a product perspective, can you speak to the target customer of the self-propelled windrower and how that come compares with that of combine? MARK STODDART: Yes, it really is the same. It just depends upon the geographical region and the product that you're harvesting. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Typically, you sell these products through your distribution network directly to the farmers. So we are not selling -- some small percentage, we sell to the OEMs, yes. But most of it is being sold through distribution directly to the farmers. So a farmer would buy the combine, and then they would buy their choice of harvesting equipment that would go along with that. So our FlexDrapers and Rigid Drapers would fit right onto the front of another manufacturer's combine, and that's sort of how the market works. MATTHEW T. PAIGE: Got it. Okay. And then the last question for me is you mentioned that the sum of the parts is the best way to look at Linamar. Have you considered any sort of financial engineering to better bring that value out to the market? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Well, at the moment, no. We're happy with the way the businesses are running. We're continuing to grow the businesses and scale that. The way that they're currently in the organization makes the most sense for us. OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Your next question comes from the line of Michael Glen from Macquarie. MICHAEL W. GLEN, ANALYST, MACQUARIE RESEARCH: Can you just give the rough size and revenue and maybe the EBITDA of your current agricultural business? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Oh, it's quite small. It's one small facility, less than $100 million in sales. So we mainly focus on corn heads in that facility, a few other products, but their major products from an ag perspective would be the corn heads. So it's a pretty small business today, but we think maybe alongside MacDon, we can see some good growth potential in that product. We certainly look forward to the MacDon team's insights and expertise in helping us to strategize around that. MICHAEL W. GLEN: Okay. And then the range on EBITDA margins was pretty wide at 20% to 25%. Like what's sort of the appropriate range that we should think about using as we try to model this business going forward? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Well, I mean, as noted, the $1.2 billion purchase price is a 7.8 multiple last 12-month EBITDA. So I think that gives you a pretty good sense for at least where they've been at in the last 12 months. We'd like to stick with the range because, I mean, obviously, markets go up and down and businesses was up and down. So I don't want to give you a promise on what we're going to deliver year in, year out. So I think it's good that you get a sense for the range, and you've got a pretty accurate figure for the last 12 months. MICHAEL W. GLEN: Okay. And sorry, I'm having some difficulties actually looking at the presentation through the WebEx. But what is the LTM sales number exactly? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: $600 million. MICHAEL W. GLEN: It's $600 million. And are you able to give an idea of what's the organic growth rate for the company over the past, call it, 2 or 3 years? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. High single digits, sort of mid -- let's say mid- to high single digit in the last 5 years and a similar kind of outlook in probably a little more high single digit for the next 5. MICHAEL W. GLEN: Okay. And then as we think about Linamar now as a company, I mean, balancing where we see you allocate capital between automotive, the Skyjack business and Agriculture, are these the 3 segments that you're going to focus on? Or should we think about you adding more segments? And what segment do you intend to focus on more going forward? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. So I mean, obviously we're going to be focusing on digesting this acquisition and really understanding and growing this agricultural business. With respect to capital allocation between the 3 businesses, the good news is both Skyjack and the Agriculture business are quite light -- lightly capital intensive. In fact, they're great cash generators in comparison to our capital -- very capital-intensive Powertrain/Driveline business, which is a big part of what we like about having the balance of the 2 businesses. They're very complementary from a financial and balance sheet perspective. So it's not like we're going to have to make a lot of decisions around where are we going to invest. With respect to other markets, as we talked about in our long-term plan, there are other markets that we think are interesting to grow into. We're still in the research and sort of strategy building phase around those segments. But they are areas that longer term, over the next 5 to 10 years, that you will start to see us expand more into. But right now, these 3 markets are great markets, lots of growth opportunity and will be our primary focus in the next several years. MICHAEL W. GLEN: And this was -- on the sale of the company, this was a competitive process that was held? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: The brothers have looked at selling the business certainly several times in the past, evaluated more than one potential buyer, and we are just thrilled that we were able to come together with them and come to an agreement this year. OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Your next question comes from David Tyerman from Cormark Securities. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN, ANALYST OF INSTITUTIONAL EQUITY RESEARCH, CORMARK SECURITIES INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: My first question is just on the synergies. Can you give us any sense of what they are? It sounded like they were small but... LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. I mean, modest synergies because they're quite different businesses, right? So as Jim was talking about some opportunities on the purchasing side probably by -- if they're buying a lot of similar things to what Skyjack might be buying. We think there's opportunities in taking our own manufacturing expertise and maybe bringing some ideas to the table there and synergies in combination with our existing agricultural business will be sort of high-level buckets. JIM JARRELL: Yes. And there might be part distribution ideas like that as well. But really manufacturing, maybe cross-channel distribution, purchasing and parts could be the areas of synergies. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Do you think this can add up to $10 million or $20 million within a couple of years? Or... LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: We haven't put a dollar value on it, David. We think there's opportunities there, and we're going to certainly dive in to see what we can find. This isn't something with massive synergies, so we haven't put a dollar number on it. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Right. And just on the sales growth, I think you said at the start, Linda, or somewhere early on that sales have run between $550 million and $650 million per year over the last 5 years. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: So is there actually a trend there like a growth trend? Or is it more that's going up and down with the market, the ag market? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: I mean, there is a growth, a long-term growth trend. The ag business has been in a bit of a down cycle over the last few years. So if you look at the last 5 years, it's probably not the most representative of the growth potential of a company. The good news is we're coming out of that cyclical low. So the market should be picking up. And our target, as described, is to grow global market share. So we should therefore see some more robust growth. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Okay. And sorry, you're saying... JIM JARRELL: Sorry, David. I was just going to say as well, if you think it through the cycle and you've got everybody sort of talking 5%, 10%, John Deere is saying that in the ag and turf, really this is really going to come back to the technology and how a farmer perceives the technology and use it. And that's where MacDon really comes in. And a lot of their growth potential is still not tapped to replenish some of those implements that are out there. So that's a lot of the growth aspect as well we see. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Right. Okay. So something like 5 to 10 for the next 12 sounds like the best guess. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. As I say, high single digit, I think, is a good estimation. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Okay. And then is there seasonality to this business? JIM JARRELL: Yes. It's similar to like what Skyjack has in that the first half of the year is fairly active. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Okay. Okay. And any thoughts on NAFTA? And if they're manufacturing is in Winnipeg, is that going to be an issue? If there are... LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. Obviously, the NAFTA question is on a lot of people's minds for a lot of different businesses. I think that first of all, if NAFTA goes away for all businesses, the natural expectation will be to revert to WTO, which is, what, 2% or 3%. But the expectation for MacDon is it would fall under the most favored nation principle, which should, for agriculture equipment, result in a 0 tariff. DAVID BRUCE TYERMAN: Okay. That's helpful. And then the last question, I guess, or comment is on the sum of parts. So it's a great idea. We would need some breakout though to do that, like EBITDA at the segment level. And presumably, we need to break Ag from Skyjack. Have you given any thoughts about if you want to go down the sum of parts approach? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. I think that the good news is that the financial metrics of the 2 businesses are pretty similar. So you don't necessarily need -- and the multiples in the industry are pretty similar for both the ag and the access. So I think that it's fine to leave them together and you can assess them in that way. OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Your next question comes from the line of Todd Coupland from CIBC. TODD ADAIR COUPLAND, MD OF INSTITUTIONAL EQUITY RESEARCH, CIBC CAPITAL MARKETS, RESEARCH DIVISION: I just had a couple of financial questions. What is the rate -- interest rate on the new debt line? DALE SCHNEIDER: It's in line with our existing debt. TODD ADAIR COUPLAND: Okay. And what will be the rough depreciation and amortization against the EBITDA? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Depreciation and amortization is pretty low, sort of 1% or 2% and the reason being that CapEx, as I mentioned, is pretty low as well. So it's not a big player. Similar to Skyjack. OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Neville from Scotiabank. MARK NEVILLE: I just want to dig a little deeper into the, I guess, international expansion. How quickly, that something you can (inaudible) after? How exactly would you do it against? It sounds like you would continue to manufacturing in Winnipeg. And I guess you would need to set up some sort of distribution network in Europe. So I guess I was just curious as to when that happens. And when do you think you'll be doing the steps you would need to do that, I guess? JIM JARRELL: Yes. They do sell internationally today. They do have plans for Europe already and they've set up a business in Europe. So really now setting up a distribution -- further distribution network and dealership. In regards to local manufacturing over there, we really haven't pursued that as of yet. That's something we need to do. Obviously, we can leverage off of both. We have the manufacturing and fabrication (inaudible) capabilities. So from a time perspective, we really don't have that nailed down yet, but we have that immediate site. MARK NEVILLE: Sorry, what did you say you had in your -- not the Oros but the -- I think you'd be hosting... JIM JARRELL: They have set up a business structure there, and they do sell into Europe today. So they have taken steps to start Europe already, and now that's what we're going to help leverage. MARK NEVILLE: And what they're selling in Europe is being manufactured in Winnipeg? JIM JARRELL: Yes, it is. OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line once again of Michael Glen from Macquarie. MICHAEL W. GLEN: I apologize. I can't look at the presentation. So you said that sales were $600 million, and the -- if you use -- the $1.2 billion was the entire enterprise value for the transaction? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: $1.2 billion is, yes, the transaction cost, which represents 7.8x EBITDA. MICHAEL W. GLEN: So the LTM margin then is kind of close to 25% right now on an EBITDA basis? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Correct. Yes. MICHAEL W. GLEN: Okay. And so is that then -- I'm just trying to assess that in terms of your guidance on the 20% to 25% then. Are we effectively at peak margin right now for the business? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Yes. I mean, I was talking about the historical level. So yes, I mean, we're at the higher end of the margin range today. MICHAEL W. GLEN: Okay. And so we should maintain that level then? LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: I think that's a realistic expectation. OPERATOR: We have no further questions at this time. I turn the call back to the presenters. LINDA S. HASENFRATZ: Okay, great. Thank you very much. Well, as usually, I'd like to leave you with 3 key messages. First, we're really excited about this great opportunity to expand our agricultural business with an innovative market leader like MacDon. Diversification is an important growth strategy for us. Second, we are very happy with the financial performance and outlook of MacDon. This is a strong, well-managed company, which is delivering earnings that will be immediately accretive to our bottom line. Our outlook for 2018 is now for strong double-digit growth, top and bottom line. And finally, despite the size of the transaction, we feel the resultant leverage of 1.7x EBITDA still leaves us with a very strong balance sheet, which we expect to rapidly delever further over the next 18 to 24 months to less than 1x. It's a strong company, great growth, great diversification and innovation and altogether makes a very great deal. Thanks very much, and good evening. OPERATOR: This concludes today's conference. Thank you very much for your participation. Have a lovely day. You may now disconnect. title: Outback Guidance Introduces New Autosteering Solution to Its Dealer Network
article: Outback Guidance Introduces New Autosteering Solution to Its Dealer Network New Outback Guidance Precision Farming Solution to be Unveiled at the Crop Production Show in Saskatoon, Canada on January 8, 2018 Hiawatha, KS, Dec. 14, 2017 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- December 14, 2017 -- Outback Guidance dealers from across North America got a sneak peek of Outback's new hands-free, hassle-free auto-steering solution this week. Outback's newest product is designed to make auto-steering accessible for all farmers and all farms. Earlier this year, AgJunction Inc. (TSX: AJX), the parent company of Outback Guidance, launched its Hands-Free Revolution campaign to make hands-free farming accessible to all farmers and new hands-free product is a driving force in this revolution. "We know that farmers have a tough job and we are committed to making it easier," said Dave Vaughn, president and CEO of AgJunction. "We continue to invest and work hard in creating simplified and affordable solutions that are accessible to all farmers no matter the size of the farm or equipment." Outback's auto-steering solution is precision farming at its best. By eliminating skips and drastically reducing overlay means the entire plot receives the right stuff to yield bountiful crops without needing excess product to ensure every spot is covered. On average, autosteering saves farmers $15 USD per acre. On January 8, 2018, the new Outback autosteering solution will be launched in Saskatoon, Canada at the Crop Production Show. Anyone not attending the show can see the new offering online the same day. About Outback Guidance About AgJunction Attachments:  (END)

title: *Agrium To Acquire Louis Dreyfus Company's Fertilizer Business In Australia >AGU
article: 12 Dec 2017 11:00 ET Press Release: Agrium to Acquire Louis Dreyfus Company's Fertilizer Business in Australia Agrium to Acquire Louis Dreyfus Company's Fertilizer Business in Australia CALGARY, AB--(Marketwired - December 12, 2017) - ALL AMOUNTS ARE STATED IN U.S.$ Agrium Inc. (TSX: AGU) (NYSE: AGU) announced today a binding purchase agreement between its Australian ag-retail business, Landmark Operations, Ltd. ("Landmark"), and Louis Dreyfus Company ("LDC") for the acquisition of Macrofertil, a fertilizer distribution business in Australia with approximately $120-million in annual sales. The business includes six fertilizer storage and distribution assets with coating and blending capabilities, and its annual sales exceed 300,000 tonnes. "This network of high quality assets will complement our existing Retail footprint in Australia, and allow us to enhance our product and service offering for new and existing Landmark customers," commented Agrium's President and CEO, Chuck Magro. Landmark is a leading agribusiness company in Australia, offering crop inputs, agricultural merchandise as well as agronomic advice and services for wool and livestock sales, finance, insurance and real estate. With approximately 400 locations, Landmark serves over 100,000 clients. The transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and is expected to close in the first quarter of 2018. title: Veritas awarded premier's award
article: Recently, Veritas Farm Management Inc. was presented with the Regional Premier's Award for Agri-Food Innovation Excellence. Veritas is a Canadian leader in the analysis of precision agriculture data. "Agricultural knowledge is a constantly evolving area of expertise and while farmers need to have a trusting relationship with their input suppliers, that trust needs to be verified so that everyone is able to keep moving forward. When it comes to agronomics, the industry often focuses on yield improvements but ultimately, it is the economics that need to be considered and measured to ensure that farming remains sustainable. The next evolution of this work will focus on understanding and measuring how the interactions of multiple production variables create a cumulative profitability increase" said Aaron Breimer, Business Manager of Veritas Farm Management Inc. The Premier's Award for Agri-Food Innovation Excellence recognizes the innovative contributions of producers, processors, agri-food organizations and rural communities in Ontario. Their innovations improve existing products, create new jobs and grow Ontario's economy. In 2017, 50 award recipients were recognized, including the top Premier's Award, Minister's Award, and three Leaders in Innovation award winners. "The agriculture industry is buzzing about the potential of Big Data and what it could mean for farmers and the industry in general while this concept is an example of Deep Data that recognizes the uniqueness of each farm and field and looks to identify profitable production opportunities" explains Paul Hazzard, General Manager of South West Ag Partners Inc. Veritas Farm Management is a comprehensive farm management service that offers precision ag and farm business solutions to progressive farm and retail customers in southwestern Ontario. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of South West Ag Partners Inc. of Chatham, Ontario.

title: DVR Deveron appoints Froehlich, Sippell to advisory board
article: Deveron UAS Corp (TSX:DVR) Shares Issued 21,587,294 Last Close 12/8/2017 $0.30 Monday December 11 2017 - News Release Mr. David MacMillan reports PROMINENT INDUSTRY LEADERS JOIN DEVERON UAS ADVISORY BOARD Deveron UAS Corp. is welcoming agriculture industry leaders Art Froehlich and Dr. David Sippell to the company's advisory board. Mr. Froehlich and Dr. Sippell have a tremendous amount of experience and success in bringing new technologies to agriculture in North America. Mr. Froehlich is a board member of Richardson International Ltd. and strategic adviser and board member at AdFarm, one of North America's largest agriculture and food marketing and communications companies. Over the last 30 years, Mr. Froehlich has held senior executive positions with Hoechst Canada Inc. (Bayer), Alberta Pool (Viterra) and Westcan Malting (RAHR). He continues to work with Canadian food and agricultural companies in developing international markets for their products. Dr. Sippell has spent the past 30 years in agriculture as an entrepreneur, scientist and chief executive officer. He brings a vast knowledge base in areas of seed technology and crop protection, previously serving as head, diverse field crops, for Syngenta. Early in his career, he worked at Agricore United as general manager and at Pioneer Hi-Bred in roles ranging from pathologist to the worldwide marketing manager of Canola. He holds a PhD in plant breeding/pathology from the University of Guelph. "Our goal has been to bring North American leaders from the agriculture industry together to find ways to provide value to growers using data," commented David MacMillan, president and chief executive officer of Deveron. "Art and David bring a phenomenal amount of experience to our team in commercializing new products in agriculture. Our entire team is looking forward to working with them as we expand Deveron's data service network in North America." Mr. Froehlich commented: "In all my years in agriculture, I have seen a lot of new technology introduced to farms across North America. I see drones as another transformative idea that will bring new forms of information to farmers, enabling them to make more efficient decisions. From my involvement in some of the first forms of transgenic canola technology to various improvements in livestock and row crop, I'm looking forward to seeing how drones may have similar impact on North American farms." "Agricultural productivity is advancing at an incredible rate. Integration of technologies will further increase speed of change. Farmers' ability to lead change is being driven by adoption of technology," commented Dr. Sippell. "I believe Deveron and its drone data services are perfectly positioned to be the next great integrator and their customers will increasingly adopt data-based precision farming technology. With leadership from the Deveron team, farm productivity will continue to improve as drone-collected data ensures efficiency of inputs, to maximize quality and yield." About Deveron UAS Corp. Deveron is a nationally compliant, Transport Canada-licensed, UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle) operator providing enterprise drone data services to agriculture. Deveron's data help farmers increase yields and reduce costs using sophisticated unmanned aerial systems, sensors, software and analytics. Deveron's drone data service network allows enterprise-level customers to obtain on-demand, actionable data without exposure to technology and capital risks. We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Andersons Inc 2017 Investor Day - Final
article: Presentation JOHN KRAUS: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to The Andersons 2017 Investor Day. I'm John Kraus, I'm the Director of Investor Relations, actually the first full-time Director of Investor Relations for The Andersons. I'm a 30-year employee at The Andersons. Spent the first half of my career directing our tax function and after that, moved to lead our accounting and finance organization in our Rail group. So really happy to have you here. I am, I guess, the master of ceremonies. You didn't come to hear me, you came to hear our senior management team and they're all here today, which is actually, we have found a feat. We sometimes need to get to New York to get them all together. So I have a couple -- and I just don't have the clicker. Oh, Pat's got the clicker, thank you. I have a couple of just housekeeping items to take care of. First of all, I think you'll all be happy to hear that we're going to make some forward-looking statements today and you're all familiar with the safe harbors that go with that. And so we want to -- just want to have you spend a moment or two in your books, taking a look at that information. I also want to point out that we have -- we'll make some references to some non-GAAP measures and there's some information in the back of your books that reconciles the non-GAAP measures to some GAAP measures, for those of you who are interested in that kind of information. With that, I'd like to just quickly go over the agenda for today. The day is basically 6 presentations, the first one by our CEO, Pat Bowe, followed by a couple of our group presidents presenting. Then we'll take a break for Q&A and then a little refreshment break. We'll come back, we'll do the presentations for the 2 other groups and then John Granato, our CFO will finish up with the finance organization. We'll do another Q&A presentation and then we'll adjourn to the room on my left, your right, for lunch. And we'd really like to invite you to stay for lunch. That will give you an opportunity to have some good one-on-one time or more private time to ask questions you might not want to ask in this setting. We do have also -- I want to welcome our web audience. We are webcasting this live. And web participants are also going to be able to ask questions, which will be minor during the course of the day. And so hopefully, we'll have a chance to answer some of those as well. With that, I'd like to start by showing you a little more about The Andersons. (presentation) PATRICK E. BOWE, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, THE ANDERSONS, INC.: As a season for many of you the next couple of weeks and making time and some of you traveling from out of town to be here is really greatly appreciated. We're super excited to be here at the leadership team of Anderson to tell our story. We've had a lot going on the last couple years and we thought, this was a very perfect time to do this. So I've just hit the 2-year mark as the CEO of the Andersons and in that time, we've had a lot of change. We knew we have some tough flooding in some of our markets and we had to make some tough decisions, worked on our portfolio and rationed some assets, downsized some people in the process, and also had some growth opportunities that we've been pursuing. So we also have change of leadership that's happening right now. We're having a couple retirements, the group President, so you'll hear more about that later, who our new Presidents are and the transition we're going through right now, so we're excited. This was a good time to share our story with all of you. Oops. There we go. So what I wanted to start with, many of you I've met before but a little bit -- we're all going to do a little introduction about ourselves. In the back of the book, we have bios on all the senior leaders of the company, so you can read about that. My background comes from I'm an ag guy, as they say, right? So my father was in the grain business, and miniature Andersons, if you will. So he ran a grain elevator and sold seed and fertilizer in Stockton, California, the central valley of California for over 40 years, owned and operated that company, which is still going today 120-year-old company. And so the [kind of] the DNA little bit was around I am not a farmer, so I didn't have dirt under my nails, but around trading most my life. I want to college at Stanford and played football there, did a brief stint with the Green Bay Packers before I went to work for Louis Dreyfus, another grain trading company and was located in Springfield, Illinois. And when I was there in the early '80s, I traded grain everyday with this company called The Andersons, and they were one of our biggest suppliers at that time for export to the East Coast and to the Gulf. And so I have this great respect for the Anderson family, the traders who worked there, and they just had a really unique esprit de corps amongst employees and always thought highly of the Andersons. Fast forward, I went back to Stanford for grad school and get a Master's at the food research Institute, which sounds like you're learning to flip hamburgers, that's not what it is. It's kind of an ag business policy, focused mostly on the futures markets and went to work straight to the Board of trade for there for Cargill. I worked for 30 years for Cargill in a myriad of roles. We moved 8 to 10 times, lived in Latin American and Brazil and all around the Midwest, manufacturing, running plants, sales, sales management, and spent 8 years as the President of the U.S. Corn Wet Milling business, about a $6 billion domestic business. And in the last 8 years at Cargill was the Corporate VP of our Food Ingredients platform. With other colleagues, we ran a $30 billion business in some 30 countries, so a lot of travel and fun involved in that. Then I got a phone call one day. And when you all get phone calls, I mean I didn't usually pay attention. They said hey, we're looking for someone to be the CEO of The Andersons. Go back 30 years, last time I was in Toledo, Ohio was at the Andersons farm in Maumee for the Toledo board and trade picnic. And I said, wow that's a great company and I wanted to listen and find out about it. And what I thought was, I knew ag was going to have a tough time. We have had the ag super cycle, if you want to call it from '11 to '14, really good time for all of us in ag space. I knew it was coming off and came off pretty hard. I saw that the Andersons' stock had fallen from $60 to $25. And I thought hey, it's time for a change and maybe I can be the change agent at The Andersons to really make the turnaround happen. I had experience with that before because when I took over the corn milling job, the business had slumped dramatically in the '90s with too much capacity. And over 8 years there, we tripled the top line from $2 billion to $6 billion, and took a tenfold increase in earnings from $25 million to $250 million. So I've been part of turnarounds, doing tough things. We laid off 10% of our workforce the first year, that wasn't the most popular of things. I kind of knew what that would take and knew that The Andersons was a perfect opportunity for me because of the ethics and the values of the company. So when you talk to anyone in the grain, rail, ethanol, fertilizer business, talking about The Andersons, they are quality people. Their words are bond, they always back it up with what they say. And that's the kind of company I want to work for. In our local community, in some way The Andersons are almost worshiped. They've had generations of giving back to the community and that's a fun place to work I'll tell you. And you can't build that overnight and a lot of companies lose it pretty quickly. You've known many of us falling from grace. So it's something we cherish and think about, that's something we don't want to change. What we do what a change in other ways, we're going to talk about today. So thanks for listening a little bit to my background. With that, I'd share a story with and I'll start off with the kind of some key messages you're going to hear throughout the day. It's a little bit of a theme. One, I've told you about this well-respected legacy we have. Also said we're in the early innings of a recovery. So for you baseball fans here, you kind of get what early innings is. You pick the inning, and I don't know if it's second or third but we're beginning to feel like we're getting the starts of a turnaround in our business. You're going to meet some new leaders today. It's an interesting time when I came to the company of the senior leadership team of 10, 9 were in their 60s. There's nothing wrong with being 60, being 59 myself, but we had several people that are approaching retirement. It's just kind of a natural progression, and The Andersons grew dramatically and all these leaders built this company to where it is, and it's great that they can go out with a great retirement at the right time. And so we knew that coming and we had some succession gaps. And so we brought in some outside talent and I'll tell you more about that later. But that's some of -- a part of what we're going to share today. We've also been proactively managing the key performance drivers. So in ag markets, those of you who follow ag know we have cycles, right? And so, what do you do when you have tough cycles? You focus on what you can control. And we were after our cost, our efficiency, productivity, having the right people in the right places, and that's kind of what we can control. We have a very solid balance sheet. Good news, we have several of our banker friends in the room here who are great support to us. But we have available free cash flow to grow the company. Even in this dip of this tough cycle we've been in, we still have a strong balance sheet and have the ability to invest and grow the company. We've also been -- big focus -- I come, I quoted, for a long time in plants and operations. First thing I hit the ground was safety, big improvement on safety we need to make to be world class and 0 if possible. And we've had great strides already. Also on productivity, setting productivity targets for the company, for the businesses, for each group, for each location, and measuring those metrics. And then we also worked on our portfolio. And we'll share a little bit more about that later. We had to turn some assets that weren't performing for us, or locations that didn't look like they had a growth path. And lastly, just build on that value system I talked about but also drive a cultural transformation of accountability. So we can deliver and if you're a salesmen, you have goals, you have targets, they have to hit those targets. Our plan has expectations on yield and production for the day, and those are your key objectives you need to hit. So we've been pushing that throughout the organization so it can be faster, nimbler and more agile, which is part of the focus we've been putting together. Here are the 5 things at the corporate level throughout each of the business President's presentations. For some of you who know our company very well, and a couple of you may just be new to it, an at-a-glance look at the company, some basic facts and figures. We were founded in 1947 by Harold Anderson, and the company was under private ownership as the Anderson family grew. And there's a lot of Andersons, those of you who know us. And they are a very entrepreneurial bunch, who built this company up and then went public 21 years ago. In fact, I had the great pleasure a year ago to be here with Mike Anderson where we got to ring the NASDAQ bell for our 20th anniversary. I was really disappointed, I'd always seen it on TV where you bring the big board bell. When you got to NASDAQ, it's a little studio, it's all like fake, everyone can see the difference. Still cool, still cool. Some big numbers and you're going to learn more from our group Presidents here later, but the $55 million in Grain and $40 million in Plant Nutrition and $45 million ethanol and $62 in Rail, all were a top 10 player in each of our industries. When the last frack sand boom -- when we didn't have enough small cube covered hoppers built, we, in fact, did put a lot of big cars, grain cars into sand service. Today, the situation is not there. We built enough sand cars over the last few years to take care of that demand. It is not that it can't be done. It is too big a car for the bulk density of the product. So on a very selective, very high-demand market where they cannot get the small cube covered hoppers, we could send some of our 47, 50 cubic foot covered hoppers to grain cars to take care of that. JOHN KRAUS: Okay. Do we have any more questions from our audience? Okay, with that, I would really like to thank you again for the investment of 0.5 day in The Andersons and your attention to our story. We're proud of the company. We're excited for the future, and we would again really like to invite you to lunch next door. We'll have a couple of members of our management team at each table. So maybe you can pick your spots based on your particular interest. And again, thanks for coming, and we wish you safe travels back home. PATRICK E. BOWE: And happy holidays, and please join us for a Q&A follow-up and for lunch next door. We'll all be sitting there and love to have any other conversations you'd like to have. Thanks again. Thank you for here. JOHN J. GRANATO: Thank you. JOHN KRAUS: Thank you.
