title: Government urged to help with climate adaptation; There is a need for more research and promotion of different farming practices
article: There is much governments can do to help farmers adapt to climate change through agriculture research and promoting different farming practices, says Evan Fraser, Canada Research Chair in Global Food Security at the University of Guelph. It's crucial for governments to act because agrifood has the potential to boost its contribution to the national economy, he told the Senate agriculture committee which is studying the impact of climate change on farming. "There's a golden moment and a golden opportunity here for Canadian agriculture and that this opportunity was recognized by Dominic Barton in his report from the Advisory Council on Economic Growth earlier this year," he said. The government has a key role in making the golden moment reach its potential. He recommended the government "incentivize breeding programs, both for our crops and for our livestock that promote heat tolerance, drought tolerance or pest tolerance. ... For much of the 20th century, our breeding programs focused on simply boosting yields at the exclusion of traits such as resilience." "But I think by shifting government funding programs to support research into climate-resilient crops and livestock and then by engaging in public-private partnerships with input suppliers, we can provide farms with the genetic tools they need to adapt. "Similarly, we can also create incentives for farmers to use more agri-ecological principles that will help improve resilience as well," he said. "Creating incentives to encourage crop rotation or conservation practices help because these practices build up the organic matter in our soils, and this is important because organic matter acts like a sponge, trapping water when it's abundant and saving it for when it's needed." The committee should also focus on agriculture's potential to use technology to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions, he said. Digital technologies, "which include smart tractors that know where they are in the field and plant the right seed in the right place and give it the right amount of fertilizer with no waste, are sometimes called Agriculture 4.0." 'They give us the opportunity to produce more food with fewer greenhouse gas emissions, and since agriculture is responsible for a third of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, this is really important. "At the moment, however, Ag 4.0 is in its infancy, both in Canada and internationally," he said. "For instance, it requires huge amounts of data to be integrated. That smart tractor needs to take soil maps, needs to integrate it with Environment Canada weather station data and needs to take remote sensing data from our satellites and bring it all together. "At the moment, this sort of data integration isn't happening, and as a result, we as a global society as well as a country are not realizing the potential of these new technologies," he said. "I think this, however, represents an ideal opportunity for Canada to show leadership." Ottawa could help by "developing protocols pertaining to data sharing, cybersecurity, data ownership and data integration that would apply across the entire agri-food sector and make Canada a leader in developing and applying the technologies that will allow us to produce more food with fewer greenhouse gas emissions." The committee should also consider carefully the agriculture potential of Northern Canada as the climate warms, he said. "Our northern soils are very fragile and are huge reservoirs of carbon." "Some work I've been involved in suggests that if we start seriously cultivating northern soils, we will create huge new carbon emissions that will destroy Canada's ability to meet our Paris accord commitments." "This doesn't mean that agriculture can't happen; it means we have to be creative about it. "Maybe instead of thinking about wheat fields or soybean fields in the North, we think about extensive bison or caribou production that is then deliberately marketed to international discriminating markets," he said. Adaptive farming practices and expanded use of digital technology could help the agrifood sector "become more adaptable to climate change and extreme weather but also reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and build new export markets by demonstrating to our trading partners that our food is the most sustainably produced in the world, thereby establishing a brand Canada." "Similarly, I think we can develop secondary markets to sell climate-friendly agricultural technologies to our trading partners."

title: EUO Eurocontrol loses $1.39-million in Q3 2017
article: Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc (TSX-V:EUO) Shares Issued 90,750,238 Last Close 11/30/2017 $0.075 Thursday November 30 2017 - News Release An anonymous director reports EUROCONTROL REPORTS THIRD QUARTER 2017 RESULTS Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. has filed its financial statements and management's discussion and analysis for its third quarter ended Sept. 30, 2017. Financial and operating highlights - Revenue from continuing operations of $1,761,005 in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2017, an 86-per-cent increase from revenues in the same period in 2016; - Gross profit of $265,478 and $859,586 in the respective three- and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30, 2017; - Recognized second quarter net loss excluding discontinued operations of $3,746,226, compared with a net loss of $3,942,113 in 2016; - Year to date 2017 investment in research and development of approximately $2.4-million. In the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2017, revenue, excluding discontinued operations, increased to $1,761,005 from $947,484 for the same period in 2016. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for the three-month period ended Sept. 30, 2017, remained consistent at $(1,474,501) compared with $(1,463,945) for three months ended Sept. 30, 2016. EBITDA for the nine-month period ended Sept. 30, 2017, was $(4,248,907) compared with $14,335,515 for the same period in 2016. This decrease in EBITDA was due primarily to the one-time gain realized by the company on the sale of its former subsidiary, Global Fluids International (GFI) SA, to SICPA SA on Jan. 4, 2016, and higher sales and marketing expenses incurred during the first nine months of 2017. For the three- and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30, 2017, the company had gross profit of $265,478 (2016 -- $154,568) and $859,586 (2016 -- $362,571), respectively, representing an increase of 72 per cent and 137 per cent in these periods in 2017 compared with the same periods in 2016. The company recorded a net loss of $1,395,949 and $3,746,226 in these three- and nine-month periods in 2017, compared with its net loss of $1,189,360 and $3,942,113 for the respective comparative periods in 2016, primarily as a result of the increased gross profit from continuing operations. Bruce Rowlands, chairman and chief executive officer, stated: "We are pleased with the solid growth in revenue from continued operations in the nine month reporting period in 2017 compared to the same period in 2016, and our potential to continue this trend in the future through increased sales of our renewed Xenemetrix product line. Given the superior performance that has been achieved in a variety of semiconductor applications tested to date by our XwinSys team, we plan to continue our customer development initiatives, however with the expected long and unpredictable sales cycle for this new metrology technology, Eurocontrol has integrated certain XwinSys personnel within Xenemetrix's operations to consolidate and reduce expenses to ensure continuity of technological know-how whilst XwinSys continues to engage with its potential customers. With regard to Croptimal, our disruptive precision agriculture testing technology is continuing to deliver positive results providing us with an opportunity to leverage our investment with potential partners." Subsequent to the end of the third quarter, Mr. Rowlands has completed his consulting obligations to SICPA GFI as described in the purchase agreement between Eurocontrol and SICPA Finance SA that was finalized Jan. 4, 2016 -- Mr. Rowlands took no compensation for his contribution. Financial performance for the third quarter is summarized in the table.  About Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. Eurocontrol is a TSX Venture-Exchange-and-OTCQB-traded company that specializes in the acquisition, development and commercialization of innovative test and measurement technologies for industry with application technologies focused on the energy security, semiconductor and precision farming sectors based on Xenemetrix's core technological platform of ED-XRF. Eurocontrol has three wholly owned subsidiaries, Xenemetrix, XwinSys Technology Development and Croptimal, and an agreement with SICPA for semi-annual earnout payments of 5 per cent (minimum $9-million over six years) on revenues generated from the oil and gas marking and monitoring field relating to the sale of its former subsidiary Global Fluids International (GFI). We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan Inc at Citi Basic Materials Conference - Final
article: Presentation P.J. JUVEKAR, GLOBAL HEAD OF CHEMICALS AND AGRICULTURE AND MD, CITIGROUP INC, RESEARCH DIVISION: (technical difficulty) And we are pleased to have Jochen Tilk, PotashCorp's CEO. He joined the company in 2014. Mr. Tilk became -- came to PotashCorp after a 30-year career in the mining industry. As many of you know, PotashCorp and Agrium, they're closing their historic merger, which is scheduled to consummate pretty soon. So for an update on that transaction and an update on global potash fertilizer markets, please join me in welcoming Jochen to the podium. JOCHEN E. TILK, CEO, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, POTASH CORPORATION OF SASKATCHEWAN INC.: Good to see you, P.J. Good morning. Actually, I think I'm mic-ed up, so I should be able -- excuse me, I should be able to stand here and speak. Can everyone hear me very well? Excellent. Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here and return. Thank you, P.J., for the introduction. I am here today to give you a few updates after the slide -- the obligatory slide. And what I wanted to speak today is, firstly, a bit of an update on markets, and I'll do focus on the potash market, but I'll speak a bit on nitrogen and phosphate. I'll give you a bit of a perspective that we have where we think directionally things will go. And also, I'd like to give you a bit of a very brief update on the merger between PotashCorp and Agrium and what we think will happen in the next couple of weeks. First, company overview. Most of you are familiar with PotashCorp of Saskatchewan. Potash is our core nutrient and has been for many years. Last year, our gross margin or contribution in gross margin was about 53% of Potash. And historically, it's 55, 60-ish, so very consistent with the past. Nitrogen and phosphate tended to be contributors, but you can see that the phosphate piece in this pie has shrunk quite a bit. And that's really the situation in phosphate and certainly our cost position in phosphate. I'll speak to that a little bit more. But that's our distribution. Of course, after the merger, that will change, and the new company, Nutrien, will have a distribution of gross margin, which is quite different because obviously, 2 companies bring in 2 different portfolios but very complementary portfolios, I should say. I'll start with a market update, and then I'll move from the general market on crop to the nutrient markets, to the fertilizer markets. And then I'll highlight potash, and I'll speak about some of our thoughts on historic demand, inventory buildup versus actual demand and then where we see the next couple of years should go. And I'll speak to the supply and demand as well, that -- the S&D always is the big question, the big elephant in the room. In terms of crop prices, and if you look at the last 3 years, it's a bit of a boring story, to be fair, because the price this year in 2017 compared to the average -- rolling average over the last 3 years has been fairly consistent. When you look at soybean, corn sugar and palm oil, not a lot of change. The good news is, and I'll show that later, that in -- as a percentage, fertilizer affordability is actually -- has actually improved and is consistently high, which speaks to the supporting the application of nutrients. Going to the countries just in a bit more detail. India has had a good year. Monsoon has been quite good. The government has implemented some policy, some high import duties on oilseed products. But overall, as you know, the years in India tend to be a lot weather driven, and this year, the monsoon has been good. Asia. Our palm oil's prices remain supportive. 2016 was a year of drought. And Asia, driven by Malaysia, Indonesia, is actually coming back, bringing yields up in those plantations again. And we see that in the demand for potash. In particular, palm oil is a huge consumer -- or palm oil plants -- oil palms are a huge consumer of potash. The other story in Asia is that food and food quality and food -- demand on food is going up quite a bit. And that's most driven by either growth in population but also in the demand for higher-quality, higher-protein foods. North America. The story here really is that once again, we had a higher-than-expected crop. Those who follow the USDA predictions, and I think most of you do probably, somewhere midyear, it all shifted, and soybean and corn once again tend to be somewhat higher than expected. So this would be almost the fifth year in a row that we had normal crops. Of course, the -- that bodes for lower prices in the crop, and we see that in corn, and we see that in soybean. But on the other hand, American farmers are depleting soils. They know that. And so at the end of each -- one of these record years, we tend to see very high demand in nutrients to replenish that. And potassium is one of the demands or one of the nutrients that tend to be focused on replenishing soils. Latin America. Driven mostly by Brazil, it's been another very good year. We see favorable barter ratios in Brazil and have been for a while, that always supports fertilizer demand. We see a continuing story in the expansion of acreage. Brazil is one of the few countries in the world that's still adding land to farming. It has slowed down a little bit, and we see an increased focus on the safrinha planting, which is the second crop in the year which has grown in significance. And what it does actually for us, it kind of equals the demand a little bit because it takes some of the seasonality out. And China finally. We see farm consolidation. China is a story -- when we talk about crops, we tend to think North America, Brazil, which is corn and which is sugar, which is soybean. But thinking crops as well as cash crops like vegetables, fruits, which demand a lot more fertilizer, and China has a good soy population. China loves that, demands that, and the input on fertilizer there is significantly higher than it is in some of the more generic crops that we see across North America and Brazil. And so when we think crop prices, we also have to think domestically what that means in China for those. And then we see some reduction in the subsidy corn prices, but it's somewhat offset by the ethanol policy in China, which actually supports planting of corn. So a bit of an equilibrium on that front. So in summary, the year has been good, in particular in terms of output, which as long as fertilizer is affordable, for us is a positive story because it means replenishing and putting fertilizer into the ground. So what does that mean for pricing in general? I start with the 3 nutrients, and I'll focus in on potash from a longer-term picture. Potash is certainly affordable in terms of pricing. We've seen a good appreciation. Prices are up year-over-year, approximately 20%, which is a great story for us. And I have a bit of a chart that breaks that down later on. The agronomic need, which means the ratio of nutrients, is driving that as well. We look at a number, for example, the N-to-K ratio or NPK ratio, but I'll take N-to-K, which is nitrogen to potassium. And countries like India put a lot more nitrogen into the ground, as you know, than potash. But the agronomic analysis, which suggests to balance it out in time, that's certainly a scientific point. But we see that trend moving. People actually focus on that as they put nutrients into the ground. And that's been supported by relatively good affordability in relation to the crop prices that I mentioned. We look at nitrogen, we've seen strong demand, and we've seen reduced Chinese exports now in the second year. Exports year-over-year are down almost 40%. And I think people asked a year ago, is the reduction of local domestic nitrogen production in China, is that sustainable? And I think the answer today, I would say, it is sustained because of environmental policies, because of the high cost. There's incremental production coming in of nitrogen in China that will replace some of that, but the question will be, is that just a displacement of old production? Or is that new production? I think overall, I'd say we believe that the reduction of output in China is sustainable, and that has an impact. We do expect volatility in pricing for a number of reasons. And some of the main reasons is there is new production that has come on in the United States, a number of plants. That's now leveling off, and there is some curtailment that takes place at lower prices in nitrogen. Russia, as an example, that has an impact. Overall, from a trend perspective, we do think that the nitrogen picture will improve in 2018, particularly in the second half into 2019. That volatility will be there, but the -- essentially, the new production will flow through the system, will be absorbed and that the reduction of Chinese production there for export will be sustained. In phosphate, we've seen seasonal demand. You can see that little peak there on the top line. There's essentially an adjustment to seasonal demand mostly because of input pricing. Input price is going up. Sulfur has gone up. Ammonia has gone up. And that's translated into MAP and DAP production. We do think the longer-term story would be impacted by expansions by OCP and Martin. They will -- they have announced and they have said so, that they will continue to -- and along that effort. And I think that will have -- that will weigh on the market. In particular, North American producers like us, we think our costs are higher, our costs or WACC. And so for -- so when we look at the longer-term story in phosphate, somewhat less bullish perhaps than we do in potash and nitrogen. So that's the overall picture in all 3 nutrients. Just going to potash and just making a point in affordability, which is a big driver. Comparing that to last year and the year before, and you'll recall that the 3-year average of crop price has been relatively consistent. What has changed is that prices have come down. This is a chart that shows the percentage of crop prices as an index of nutrient prices, in this case, potash prices. And then next, because we put a bunch of crops together, and the index for potash means we put a bunch of different prices in the world, FOB and CFR together. The higher that number is, that means crops are, relatively speaking, higher priced. The lower the number is, it means fertilizer is higher priced. And you can see that particularly in 2017, the affordability has been consistently high compared, for example, in 2015. And that means that farmers, despite what crop prices are today, certainly are intrigued and incentivized to put in additional crops to be sure -- sorry, additional nutrients to be sure that the soil is balanced. Potash consumption and shipment growth. This is a chart that looks at the consumption of potash in the last 5 years. And it's 2013, the last 4 years, plus 1 year looking forward. So 2018 is a forecast. And then we offset that chart essentially with potash shipment growth. So the point here is whether demand and shipment are equal. And you think in time, it does, but there's always the question about inventory buildup and whether or not some potash goes into inventory and what is the impact. If you look at the last 4 years plus 2018 looking forward, and there's good visibility in 2018, just the way the contracts have worked, just the way some of the producers, us included, know what -- in particular the first half of 2018, what it will look like, I think this is a pretty good representation of 5 years. And you can see that the demand story is really driven by China and India for potash and Asia and South America. As expected, not so much by North America because we have a very consistent demand as we had in the past going forward. But on the average, the increase in fertilizer and potash fertilizer consumption has been 4%. And these are [serous] numbers, by the way. These are not numbers that we've put in so there's hopefully less of a -- or no bias on those numbers. 4% is higher than what we have projected on average. Our projection is about 2.5% to 3%. So the last 4 years have dealt with perhaps some aberrations. And when you look at the shipment growth, that is very consistent how it corresponds to the countries. So you could see that most of the potash growth has been in China, India, Asia and Latin America, as you would expect from the previous -- from the product on the left side here. So that -- and keep that in mind as reflecting on the last 5 years. And I think we believe it certainly is an indicator on where potash should end up going forward. This chart looks back, but it also looks further into the future. So it comes about 20 years. And 17 of those are looking back retrospectively, and then 5 years are looking into the future. And this is demand for potash in different crops. As I mentioned earlier, we look mostly at grain, oilseeds, but you can see that foods and vegetables and other crops are pretty significant. The orange line is actually the potash consumption. And with exception of the financial crisis in 2007, '08, '09, in that time period, where it was truly an aberration driven by world economic events. This line is almost perfectly consistent with the demand of those crops in terms of consumption. So we look at, on an annual basis, a lot of variation. But when we look over 20 years, we simply follow the increase in demand of these crops, driven by the increase in world population. I mean, that's a simple statement in its way, but it's certainly one supported by this chart. And when you look into the future, as long as you believe that those years will continue to grow as they have in the past, that should translate almost immediately into the same increase of potash fertilizer consumption. When you look at the other side of the equation, which is the supply and demand, the S&D part, it's always been a story that there was more operational capability in potash than there was actual demand. And this has been historically, as you know, part of how the potash market has worked. We anticipate some of that going forward with existing production capability, with new production capability, but that will level out eventually. So if you take this graph out another couple of years, that red line will level out just given that virtually all the projects are now coming into fruition -- have come into fruition and will be operational at their capability in the next couple of years. And of course, the green bar, we expect to continue to grow. And when you look at where we expect that to be, somewhere around 70 million tonnes by 2020, which is consistent with the growth projection of the previous slide. The big point here is that our view is that operation capability and demand are relatively close together as they have in the past. So there is not really a big change. And we saw that particularly in the last year, in 2017. The demand has been the real story for us. We have been sold out most of the year. Canpotex has been sold out most of the year. I think our competitors were committed most of the year. And we anticipate a similar picture in 2018, a very tight narrow balance consistent with the past, which, in our opinion, bodes well for the trends that I've outlined in some of the previous slides. A couple of comments about our strategic focus. So I talked about the crop markets. I talked about the fertilizer nutrient market, specific about potash, what we see in demand growth, how we think inventories will measure up and then certainly looking into the future in terms of supply and demand. How do we position ourselves? And a couple of years ago, I spoke about 4 specific strategic focus areas when I came on as CEO 4 years ago. One was that we would continue to respond to markets in our potash approach, that we would modify or adjust our assets in a way that we will only produce what was demanded in the market. And we have done consistently so. We have certainly adjusted some of our mines. An example that we put up here is that one of our mines, we turn into an all-white soluble fertilizer producer, away from the generic fertilizer so that we would capture that higher margin and not necessarily be left with incremental capacity. The second focus on that was a portfolio optimization. We were committed not to run at a higher cost, that we would move consistently our operations away into the lowest quartile that we could -- or in the lower quartile. And we've done that in a number of ways. We've suspended one of our mines in New Brunswick because it was higher cost. We focused on Rocanville, our flagship now, which has production capability of 6.5 million tonnes per year. It's the world's largest potash mine at this point. And we've reduced our cost about 50% over time by bringing our cash costs down consistently. And part of that was the reduction, the suspension of high-cost operation. The other part was the support and building up capacity of our lowest-cost operations. Financial flexibility. We're devoted to make sure that our balance sheet was pristine. We've taken some difficult steps. We cut our dividend twice. But we also reduced our capital. And 2 years ago, our capital outflow was $1.2 billion. This year, in 2017, it will be about $600 million or even less than $600 million, which is half of what we spent several years ago. So we've focused on financial prudence, not bringing -- just bringing our operating costs down but also our capital. And we realigned the dividend, as I mentioned, to be more consistent with market but also more consistent with our balance sheet. And the other strategic focus that we looked at was diversification, looking at building the company and growing. And of course, P.J. said in his announcement, that resulted in the merger with Agrium, which we announced in September a year ago and that we anticipate to close by the end of the year. And of course, I'll say a few more words to that in a second, but this merger has so much strategic benefit to us in terms of synergies, in terms of strategic opportunity and growth in terms of diversification, that we certainly are very pleased having moved forward on this particular objective. One slide I wanted to show and conclude on, on my comments on potash, and I alluded to that, is just to keep in mind how the year has improved from last year. On those -- through it, when we talk about what potash -- how potash responds in our P&L, it's really 3 things. It's the sales price -- the average sales price; the volume that we sell, and of course, the cost of goods at which we produce it. In all 3 areas, we've seen tremendous improvement over the year. So when we look at the average realized price, which is a composite of all the markets we sell to, including Canpotex or our part of Canpotex, prices have gone up about $25, $29, which is almost 20%. I mentioned it early. That's a significant trend from '16 into '17. The volumes for us, these are our volumes shipped, have gone up 7% in the 12-month period, which is important for us because it happened at the same time price has gone up. And then as I mentioned, our cost of goods have come down and, in the 12 months alone, have come down 16%. In the 5 years, our costs are down about USD 50. So that's just the story for us in the last 12 months in potash. And we're certainly influenced by that in -- looking into 2018. My final comments are just on the merger. The -- we have received regulatory approval, which was the biggest hurdle, I think, for us in general in the countries. In 5 of the 6 countries, Brazil, Canada, China, India and Russia, we have made some concessions, and we have committed to divesting of our minority investments in Arab Potash Company, in ICL and in SQM. And we're in the process of doing so. We have -- we're now in the final stages of discussing with the Federal Trade Commission in the United States. We do anticipate and we continue to believe that we'll be able to close our transaction by the end of the year. So as you know, and you've seen the announcement, Agrium has divested of 2 of its assets: the nitric acid plant in North Bend; and Conda, one of its phosphate mines. And we believe that complies with the expectations of the FTC, which will allow us to close by the end of the year. And the remedies that we have agreed to, which is the sale of our equity investments, are not expected to impact our annual synergies at all because none of these assets were actually part of that. And quite on the contrary, to be fair, I mean, we think that the opportunity to sell our investments in SQM, APC and ICL allow us to really look forward on the number of funds. We can look at how we can improve our balance sheet in terms of credit rating and our debt ratios. We can look at how we can allocate capital to support our shareholders. There's a couple of opportunities. And we can look at growing the company on its cores, which is retail and the other nutrients. And of course, all of that would be discussed by the Nutrien -- by Nutrien as a company, Nutrien management and the Nutrien board. So we very much look forward to closing transaction and getting going on that. I think it'll be a phenomenal company with lots of opportunities, as you can see on our side. And Agrium obviously has equal opportunities to bring to that new company, Nutrien. Thanks very much. And P.J., I'm not sure if there's any questions. Questions and Answers P.J. JUVEKAR: Let me start with a couple of questions. So thank you for the presentation. I'm looking at your divestments, especially of SQM, given that SQM has lithium. Lithium, as we know, a very hard market, as you know, and there is lot of interest in lithium. So can you talk about the level of interest you've received from prospective buyers? I would imagine the Chinese would be interested in getting their hands on lithium. Can we just talk to that? JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. I mean, I certainly do. And you can think about timing. As you know, the divestitures of these 3 assets was -- is a remedy that we have agreed to with the Competition Commission of India, CCI. So we did volunteer. However, the timing of that is interesting because the lithium market, as you say, is booming, and SQM or [Soc Quimic] has become perhaps more of a lithium company than it is a fertilizer company. That translates into significant interest. I won't specifically talk who is interested and number of bids and these things. I can't say that. But you can imagine that the broad interest of potential bidders and actual bidders is coming from those who are interested in lithium as a mineral, as a metal and also producers of batteries or battery parts. And many of them are in China. China is the largest consumer and largest producer of lithium products. So that's where a lot of interest is coming from. So while I can't specify who that is, and I don't want to speak too much about the actual process, but we're certainly encouraged by those factors, that lithium is a hot commodity and that the interest is broad. And given where China stands in that market, you would expect a pretty good interest coming out from that part of the world. P.J. JUVEKAR: Right. And secondly, Jochen, you sounded quite positive on nitrogen market, particularly given what has happened in China, and their export is going down. Do you foresee a scenario where China could become a net importer ever? Or do you think China will always be a net exporter? JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes, that's a loaded question. And I think we're pleased to see in -- that China's exports are not coming back up, at least don't seem to come back up. And we think it's consistent with their environmental policy, it's consistent with their social plan. And I commend China for that because I think that's the right direction. I shouldn't speak on their behalf, but it certainly is. In terms of whether that will ever swing back, China made a decision years ago to not be an importer of nitrogen and not be dependent on it. I think that was their policy decision, as they have done in phosphate. I would think they would want to sustain that. I can't imagine there's a reversal from that policy. So I'd be surprised if that would happen. So I don't want to -- I'm evading the question because I don't know, but I'd be very surprised if China would ever become an importer of nitrogen again as they have in the past because from a political perspective, they made that clear decision not to be in that position. UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: On -- there's a significant amount of Russian material that's anticipated into the potash market as of now going forward. How much do you think that has come through? Certainly, import data shows that there's been a significant uplift in certain countries importing more Russian material. Would be interested to hear your thoughts. JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. You speak specifically about EuroChem and its production coming up? UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. So when we looked at the supply and demand chart, I didn't specifically talk about the producers that are coming up. But there's really been 2. There's K+S' mine in Saskatchewan, now called Bethune, which is ramping up and is expected to be ramped up -- essentially its capacity next year; and then EuroChem's 2 mines, which are coming up just slightly behind each other. And the first mine is expected to produce a little bit this year and then more next year. So I can't speak to their approach to market. So I won't even venture into that. I mean, that will be left to them. But I'll make a couple of comments. First of all, we have seen some reduction in potash production. For example, SQM, the focus on potassium nitrate and the focus on lithium is producing less MOP generic potash. K+S has announced that it will reduce some of its production in Germany, high cost. And so there is an offsetting trend as well of reduction in production. So that's one. The second is that the market has been growing. I mean, we saw the 4% in the last 5 years as an average. We saw 8% in China, 6% in India. We expect the trend to continue. So there is room for the market to absorb that. Think about 4% as a high number. But if you take 2.5%, 2.5% of 6 million -- 65 million tonnes is somewhere 1.3 million, 1.5 million tonnes every single year on average. And K+S' production capability is 2 million tonnes and then the 2 EuroChem mines are 4 million tonnes. So if you look at that in sum, at 6 million tonnes, that's approximately 4 years of that trend if it were to continue. And those mines don't come up that fast. So will that be absorbed in 5 years? At that trend, we think absolutely yes. And that's why we believe that, that supply and demand balance is relatively tight. So they will come in, and we fully expect them to be very successful in their production, but they will come in on time. And we think on that trajectory of demand, that should be absorbed in the market. UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: In your presentation, you touched a bit about affordability. Can you maybe talk a little bit more about sort of how the elasticity of demand evolves? Is -- in an environment of flat grain prices, does that put a cap on the momentum of the different fertilizer prices that you've seen so far this year? JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. I mean, the discussion about elasticity in fertilizer, I think, is pretty old. And I know, particularly in potash, people always said there is elasticity; there is none. It's binary. What -- if I take last year, and that certainly impacted me, I do believe there is elasticity. So I believe that, and I state that as -- in my opinion, as a fact supported by that because last year, we truly saw an increase in demand based on that. People could afford it. We saw it in India perhaps more than anyone. India will come at close to 5 million tonnes, and which is significantly up from the last couple of years. And that's mostly affordability. It's not subsidies or government policy. So we think there is a fair amount of that. And you saw this index graph that we showed, and it was fairly consistent, which means from a farmer's perspective, if they put fertilizer prices as a ratio to prices they receive for their crops, it's been fairly flat. And the farmers think that way. I don't think they think about it in any other way but can I afford it in terms of what I get from my crops? So that's been fairly consistent. Would there be a point of corn would drop below $3, for example? I think you would have a contraction of the market, no question. At some point in time, it's just not sustainable. But corn right now above $3.50, we think that's still a pretty good point. So to your question, we think there is elasticity, more so in potash probably than there is in others. I mean, nitrogen will always be applied. That's just a more straightforward nutrient. We think that it's supported by the affordability, as you've seen in the graph, which has been pretty consistent, which helps. And sure, there is a point if crop prices were to drop below a certain level when there is a contraction, but I don't think we're close to that. UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And then maybe just one more quickly, I mean, a longer-term question. Some seed companies and some software companies have put a lot of resources in digital agriculture and about getting farmers to be more efficient with their fertilizer use. On that graph, you saw North America demand growth for potash pretty slow over time. If precision agriculture really picks up, what kind of long-term impact do you think that can have on demand growth? JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. I mean, markets will mature on that basis, there's no question. If you project that into the future, markets will mature and as yields will improve, relatively speaking, through precision ag. But if you look at United States, where that's the country where precision ag is probably the most established, no, not just -- likely it is the most established in the United States. And the United States is the most mature market. And if you compare that to other markets, whether it's in terms of yields, whether it's in terms of application per acre, every other market will have to migrate to that. And there's a long ways to go. I mean, that's -- if Asia and Latin America would go there, there's a long ways to go. Africa, give you an example of Africa. Africa for us has been not a real story in the last couple of years. In fact, we never spoke about it because the consumption of fertilizer generally but particularly potash in Africa was virtually nonexistent. I mean, you talk less than 2 million tonnes in sub-Saharan Africa. Credit to OCP, they have embarked in a pretty important story. They have built a number of NPK plants. They have done some joint ventures. And you look at the increase in consumption in Africa, it's quite dramatic actually year-over-year. In absolute numbers, not a big story yet, but in terms of percentage, quite remarkable. And we are shifting. We're now paying attention. We're paying attention to Africa more than we have in the past because we think that is a growth story. So yes, I think precision ag will play a role. It eventually will improve yields. But for markets to go there, there's a long ways to go, and there's lots of opportunity in between. UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I also have a question on fertilizer consumption growth. You have the slide there with regards to fertilizers in general. But for potash in particular, we've seen record yields over the last couple of years. And if you go back a couple of decades, this is a tremendous line in yield growth. Why has that not translated into equal potash demand growth in North America? And I'm not an agronomist, but the number, this 0.7% seems to be very, very tiny. JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. Let me go back to the slide so you -- that was the slide... UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: On Slide 8, I think. JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. This one here, right? UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. JOCHEN E. TILK: And your question is we've seen... UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Basically, I mean this 5 years, but I think if we go back like 50 years, the demand line for potash in North America would have been basically flat as well, although the yields have picked up dramatically. And there's obviously a need for replenishing nutrients in the ground. And I wonder why is that not the case for potash. JOCHEN E. TILK: Well, I think it is the case for potash. So in terms of the desire to replenish that in time as yields go up, I think there is a story to that. I think if you go back that far, 50 years, it was purely a nitrogen story and a phosphate story. I think the understanding of potassium fertilizers way back, I mean, talking about a couple of decades ago, wasn't there. I mean, you look at China, China was nonexistent in terms of potassium fertilizers 20 years ago. China had no domestic production and virtually didn't import anything. And that was true for many other countries. So the mature countries, Europe and North America to some extent, have picked up on that. You look at that today, and it's a different perception. I mean, China now produces 8 million tonnes. It imports the same amount, and it has a much more sophisticated way of looking how to apply that. I think it's just maturing in people's appreciation for balanced nutrient application in the ground. P.J. JUVEKAR: Maybe let me ask you one more final question. Jochen, I think you said you're not as bullish on phosphate as compared to nitrogen and potash. Phosphate has some capacity coming online with OCP, but Mosaic shut down a plant. So it seems like phosphate has less capacity coming online than potash. So wondering why you prefer potash or phosphates in terms of your outlook? I know you're a potash company. JOCHEN E. TILK: A potash company, yes. Well, I admit, I certainly have a bias, so I -- but I'll make 2 comments to that. And these are opinions; these are views. So one is it's -- when I speak about the phosphate market, I'll just speak about our phosphate. And the 2 impacts that we have, we're a North American phosphate producer. And of course, North American phosphate is more challenged than globally. We're a higher-cost producer because of the WACC that we produce, and we are more exposed to environmental constraints that impose higher operating costs. So not as -- so we're not as competitive. When you look at our potash portfolio and you look at our nitrogen portfolio, we have the best potash assets in the world -- among the best potash assets in the world. And we have among the best nitrogen assets in the world. Tremendous respect for our assets in phosphate, but from a cost perspective, we're not as competitive. So that's one part. The other one is that the phosphate market, in our opinion, is more difficult to assess, and therefore, you will have more volatility. If you look at the largest consumers of potash, the United States of 10 million tonnes; South America, 11 million tonnes; Brazil with 9 million; and then China with 15 million tonnes, 8 million is produced domestically. But they are huge importers. They -- and in fact, Brazil and U.S. produce no potash. I mean, Brazil a tiny little bit; U.S., virtually none anymore. And India -- sorry, I forgot India, at 5 million tonnes, produces no potash. So the 4 largest consumers have -- with the exception of China, have -- and China has no incremental capacity, more are importers. Whereas in phosphate, Brazil uses -- produces half its phosphate consumption. United States does. China does. So each one of these countries, they're a big consumer, but they're also a big producer. And that shifts the dynamic a little bit. So for us, we look at phosphate almost as a producer, and therefore, we're somewhat disadvantaged. But we also look at how -- the visibility that we have in potash and how we can assess that going forward. UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can I ask another question? Sorry. As you might point out, you've got nitrogen, potassium and phosphate. So you -- do you think you're increasing your presence in the NPK market now that you've got the 3 major building blocks and looking to go into more of those value-added products on a global basis? JOCHEN E. TILK: Really good question, but it's a question for Nutrien. And it wouldn't be appropriate to speak on behalf of Nutrien. What I can say is -- and is -- you can imagine that as Nutrien gets together, its board gets together and its management, one of the first things they'll do is look at the portfolio and look at exactly that, what's the right focus? What other core nutrients, whether -- if there's an opportunity to expand in specialty? I mean, those are all really good questions to look at. And the excitement around Nutrien and our own excitement to enter that stage is because we have the capability from a balance sheet perspective, from an asset perspective because you have a company that has tremendous assets in all 3 nutrients. Well, thank... P.J. JUVEKAR: Well, thank you. Oh. JOCHEN E. TILK: There was one more question? UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: If you could comment on your commitment to Canpotex and going forward, that's still in the future? JOCHEN E. TILK: Yes. We're fully committed to Canpotex. So I can say that on behalf of PotashCorp. I'd also say that on behalf of Nutrien. We've been very clear that we are committed to Canpotex and to Canpotex' future. Thank you very much. P.J. title: EUO Eurocontrol obtains fuel marking contract in Mozambique
article: Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc (TSX-V:EUO) Shares Issued 90,750,238 Last Close 11/27/2017 $0.09 Monday November 27 2017 - News Release Mr. Bruce Rowlands reports EUROCONTROL REPORTS SICPA AWARDED MOZAMBIQUE FUEL MARKING CONTRACT Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc.'s SICPA SA has been awarded a fuel marking contract for the country of Mozambique to commence implementation in the first quarter of 2018. "The contract aims to curb tax evasion in the import and marketing of petroleum products which have resulted in huge losses of revenue for the country," stated the national director of hydrocarbons and fuels, Moises Paulino. "This process will create conditions for the country's tax authority to produce more revenues." Christine Macqueen, director, corporate affairs, SICPA SA, commented: "Fuel fraud is a much greater problem than most people realize. Tackling it through molecular marking can provide additional revenue to governments to support much needed development programmes. This contract sets an example to other countries in the region." Bruce Rowlands, chairman and chief executive officer, stated: "We are pleased to announce the first new contract award for SICPA-post Eurocontrol's sale of its fuel marking technology, marketed by its former subsidiary, Global Fluids International. Earlier this year, the fuel marking contract in Tanzania was renewed by the Tanzanian government in favour of SICPA." Eurocontrol sold its former subsidiary, Global Fluids International (GFI) SA, to SICPA SA on Jan. 4, 2016, in exchange for $16-million in cash (less certain closing deductions) and postclosing earn-out payments equal to 5 per cent of the net revenues earned by SICPA GFI from related contracts entered into between Jan. 4, 2016, ending Jan. 4, 2022, with a minimum of $1.5-million per year for the six year earn-out period (total of at least $9-million). About Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. Eurocontrol is a TSX Venture Exchange and OTCQB-traded company that specializes in the acquisition, development and commercialization of innovative test and measurement technologies for industry with application technologies focused on the energy security, semiconductor and precision farming sectors based on Xenemetrix's core technological platform of ED-XRF. Eurocontrol has three wholly owned subsidiaries, Xenemetrix, XwinSys Technology Development and Croptimal, and an agreement with SICPA for semi-annual earn-out payments of 5 per cent (minimum $9-million over six years) on revenues generated from the oil and gas marking and monitoring field relating to the sale of its former subsidiary Global Fluids International (GFI). We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Soil sensors, drones and data analytics are the new tools for farmers; The seeds of technology have been planted to improve yields, efficiencies and overall business
article: Trevor Scherman had a major frost last year on his farm near Battleford, Sask., about 140 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon. Data from the nearest Environment Canada weather station, about 25 kilometres away, disagreed with him - it said there was no frost in the area. Fortunately, Mr. Scherman had his own sensors. Deployed around his 4,500-acre farm, the devices indeed recorded two days of frost, which let him approach his insurance company about covering the cost of the damage. With definitive data in hand, the insurer gave him the go-ahead to replant his crops, thereby saving the harvest that would occur months later. "I was basically done reseeding before [other nearby farmers] even considered it," he says. "If I had delayed my reseeding, by even seven days, that could have been very costly." Mr. Scherman is what you might call a data farmer. That doesn't mean he tends numbers and information all day, but rather that he applies modern technologies and the data they generate to his farm, where he grows peas, lentils and canola. Aside from the weather stations, he also uses drone footage and satellite imagery, both of which provide him with even more information about the state of his land. He's an example of a new generation of farmers that are adopting Big Data - more known for its applications in fields such as accounting and financial services - to improve yields and overall business. Agriculture experts say this new wave is gathering momentum - that the majority of farmers are now waking up to the value that technology and data can unlock. The growth of Farmers Edge can be seen as proof. Started in 2005, the Winnipeg-based company sells "precision agriculture," or weather and soil data along with the tools to gather it. Mr. Scherman is a subscriber, paying the company about $4 an acre. Farmers Edge is now up to 450 employees and operates in five countries: Canada, the United States, Australia, Brazil and Russia. In Canada alone, where there are about 200,000 farms, the company has about 2,000 clients. Its growth has been especially fast recently, with the total land it surveys for clients now at 10 million acres, up from just 800,000 acres three years ago. "We're at a tipping point in the industry," says chief product officer Patrick Crampton. "We're now getting focused recommendations and insights rather than just gathering data for data's sake." Improved satellite imagery is partly driving the momentum, he adds, since it's now more accurate, detailed and in real time. Farmers are also realizing that they can benefit from their neighbours' data as well, which is aggregated by the company. "It's opening up insights that aren't just happening on your farm," Mr. Crampton says. "Instead of learning from one season of data, you're learning from 2,000 man years of data." Despite that, many farmers are still finding challenges in accessing data because of their rural locations. In many cases, internet and wireless coverage is spotty or expensive, while power and the cost of sensors can also be challenges - especially in less-developed countries. FarmBeats, an internet-of-things platform under development by Microsoft, is trying to help on those fronts. The project is working to lower the cost of both connectivity and sensors. The software giant has been experimenting with "white spaces," or unlicensed parts of wireless spectrum that exist in between cellphone and television signals. Along with other tech giants including Google, the company believes such frequencies can provide inexpensive internet connectivity to rural communities, including farms. "You could be sending huge amounts of data where you couldn't before," says Ranveer Chandra, a principal researcher at Microsoft. FarmBeats is also working on cheaper ground-level sensors, which can currently cost as much as $8,000 (U.S.). The project has succeeded in producing a full processing unit for about $175, with the ultimate goal of getting down to about $80. Mr. Chandra also believes artificial intelligence can be applied to the sort of data that Farmers Edge gathers in order to predict future weather patterns and soil conditions. Drones, for example, can use infrared scanning to detect soil moisture levels. Over time, with enough information, the data can suggest to farmers which parts of their land need more water and which need less. "Any insights we provide, we believe are actionable," he says. "We want to take the guesswork out of farming." Sean Stratman, who runs Dancing Crow Farm in Carnation, Wash., about 50 kilometres west of Seattle, has become hooked on FarmBeats' data since he started working with the project three years ago. The project's moisture sensors have helped him to cultivate his land more precisely. FarmBeats' data has even predicted how a beaver dam that sprouted up on his land would affect moisture levels. "As I'm starting to understand the value of this data and all of the possible ways I can use it ... I'd say it's pretty much priceless," he says. "I feel like this is one of the most important tools I have in my arsenal." Despite the rapid uptake in recent years, experts believe the agricultural data revolution is still only in its infancy, with much more useful information to be unlocked over the coming years. "We're leaving a lot of data on the table," says Stanford Blade, dean of the faculty of agricultural, life and environmental sciences at the University of Alberta in Edmonton. "There's a huge amount of information that we're just starting to stumble onto." Follow this link to view this story on globeandmail.com: Soil sensors, drones and data analytics are the new tools for farmers Globe and Mail Update

title: Expanding drone tech still looking for buyers
article: Drone technology is quickly catching up to the rest of innovative farming as evidenced by Ontario-based Deveron UAS (Unmanned Aerial Systems) and their recent partnership with Monsanto subsidiary The Climate Corporation. The Climate Corporation has been collecting data for years through their Climate FieldView program. Deveron UAS's dronebased agriculture service plans to piggyback that system, giving farmers another way to precisely measure their crops and maximize their margins. That type of farming - colloquially, precision agriculture - is used by roughly 10 to 15 per cent of farmers according to Deveron UAS. "One of the challenges with agriculture and data to date has been really, how do we store it, how do we use it, and how do we integrate it?" said Norm Lamothe, farmer and head of UAS Agriculture with Deveron. "The Climate FieldView program is really designed to take all those pieces of information and be able to turn it into a meaningful solution for the grower. "All of these integration tools ... as they begin to talk to each other more and more, are going to become more valuable," he added. That's important. As farmers look toward drone technology the lingering question is whether the savings and yield improvements are worth the hefty price tag. As a result, to this point most of Deveron UAS's clients have been large-scale farmers. That could change as the technology improves and as more systems become integrated. "I know a few people who are experimenting, or working with drones," said Scott Persall, chair of the Norfolk-Elgin district of the Grain Farmers of Ontario. "There's lot of opportunities ... it's something I've thought about but I just haven't pursued." Deveron UAS has expanded rapidly since 2015. Their system employs drones to identify everything from moisture, to tile drainage, to dips in topography. When used correctly the drones help farmers maximize profits. But farmers need to understand how exactly to use the tools at their disposal, according to Dr. Ivan O'Halloran, precision agriculture professor at the University of Guelph's Ridgetown College. "It really depends on the individual farm or the individual situation," O'Halloran said. "I've not been overly impressed with any of the imagery as it relates to fertilizer requirement; again, some basic soil knowledge, landscape, tells us a lot." O'Halloran admits there are positives to glean from drone information. On the other hand, he says, farmers have to know how to use the data to their advantage. "Before we had satellite imagery," O'Halloran said. "Then we tried to get aerial photographs, and stuff like that ... the drone is allowing instantaneous evaluation of the appearance of the crop. The long and the short of it is it's still very hard to do it from a predictive standpoint." Another aspect is high speed internet. Deveron UAS's technology requires a way to transfer large quantities of data and in some places in rural Ontario that isn't possible - not over a manageable time frame, at least. Once true high speed internet is available in rural Ontario it could help push drone technology further. "Faster internet is going to help (agriculture) tech in general," Lamothe said. "The ability to move data faster, the ability to have data to access in the field, real time ... we're looking forward to see how data in rural areas improve over time." St. Thomas Times-Journal

title: New crop of farmers; Grey's AG 4.0.1 event in Meaford has added focus on youth
article: A conference touting the future of agriculture is putting a call out to the farmers of tomorrow. Grey County is presenting its AG 4.0.1 Digital Agriculture Conference on Friday at Meaford Hall, fallowing up on last year's AG 4.0 conference that focused on technology in agriculture. Touted as "The Next Big Thing," this year's conference has an added focus on youth, with free tickets offered to those between the ages of 12 and 18, and a special session geared towards the young participants. "We recognize that there is incredible innovation happening in agriculture and there are a lot of kids that are going to go away and learn about that, but they are going to want to come back," said Philly Markowitz, Grey County's economic development officer. "We want them to know that the county supports this kind of innovation and we want them to get excited and come back and implement those ideas here." Markowitz said it is important to involve youth in a conference like the one they are holding. "As technology accelerates the people who are most flexible in their ability to adapt are young people," said Markowitz. "We also recognize that rural Ontario and Grey County is aging and there are a lot of farms that don't have succession plans in place. "If we can help draw connections between the farms and farmers who are aging out and the young people who are here want to return here, then it is going to be better for everyone." The 21st Century Local Food Network youth session is being facilitated by Bernie Blakeney of the Launch Pad Youth Activity and Technology Centre in Hanover. Blakeney has created a simulation of a greenhouse growing environment along the lines of technology being used in Holland and southwestern Ontario with sensors, robotics and other controls. "He is creating something that students or anyone can access from their phones and play with as if they are running a full system," said Markowitz. "We are really excited about it and we are encouraging teenagers to bring their phones to school." This year's conference includes a streamlined program so people don't have to make as many choices around concurrent sessions. In this year's conference there is a strong focus on geographic information system and agricultural mapping. Farming by the Numbers Part 1 includes the launch of Grey's new Agri-Foods Asset Map, a tool to link the county's various agricultural assets, including producers to producers and producers to customers. The I Robot? session includes a look at farm labour trends, cutting edge technology and making the switch to robotics and other technological solutions. The event also includes an introduction to Bluewater Angels, a program that drives innovation and entrepreneurship by providing funding support for start-up businesses. Farming by the Numbers Part 2 features a trio of speakers from the Ontario Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs providing an introduction to the AgriMaps Portal and other new agricultural data tools. Big Data, Small Farm - Data Driven Agriculture addresses commodity challenges through the use of data, while in the Success Stories session, producers tell how they have adopted new technologies and how they have paid off. The Technology and Sustainability session talks about using data and technology to protect the environment and increase efficiencies. "We have panels that address the kinds of questions ask when they look to adopt a technology, questions they are asking about where the future of farming is heading, questions about the success and return on investment of making technological changes," said Markowitz. "Kind of the two main themes are what can data do for us and what does change really look like at the farm and on the farm." There will also be exhibits on hand from the Brookfield Institute, OMAFRA, Grey County planning, and a display of the Agri-Foods Asset Map. "All will give attendees an opportunity to interact, ask questions and give feedback," said Markowitz.

title: Prairie groups combine forces
article: A Manitoba artificial intelligence/machine-learning consortium didn't make the shortlist for the federal government's $1-billion supercluster funding, but it has teamed up with a Saskatchewan group for the next phase. Enterprise Machine Intelligence and Learning Initiative (EMILI) has merged with Protein Industries Canada (PIC) to form a pan-prairie proposal to access this federal government funding pool. Its goal is to position Canada globally as the leading centre of high-quality, plant-based protein production. Although the EMILI proposal was initially designed to target a broad array of vertical markets including manufacturing, efforts to deploy machine learning technologies in agriculture was always part of the concept. Ray Bouchard, the president of EMILI and the CEO of Enns Brothers, said the EMILI initiative always has contemplated working with other technology superclusters. "When we submitted under the letter of intent, we said we would be open to working with the other groups and that is what we have done," Bouchard said. "I think we have landed in a pretty good place from an EMILI perspective." The deadline for the next phase of the funding competition is Nov. 24. Bouchard and PIC acting president Ron Styles, recently retired CEO of SaskTel, said final details of the proposal are still being worked out. The proposal is focused on developing ways to increase yields and improve production on the farm. "EMILI really strengthens our proposal," Styles said. "We are going to need farmers to produce more than they have in the past per acre. So we need improved production efficiencies and technologies to get the proteins out. "In both those areas what EMILI was planning would be vital to those efforts. We see it as a natural fit within the ecosystem we want to build." Styles believes that if it is successful in landing funding from Ottawa, as well as up to $200 million in private sector venture capital investments in the various projects, it could mean a total impact of about $1 billion over the next five years. Winnipeg-based Farmers Edge, a rapidly growing global precision farming subscription service that was a major proponent of EMILI, has joined the PIC board of directors. It also had been a member of an Alberta group that is still in the running but has decided to dedicate its efforts to the Saskatchewan-based proposal. martin.cash@freepress.mb.ca

title: PotashCorp - Agrium and PotashCorp Announce Mailing of Letters of Transmittal and Election Forms to Registered Shareholders
article: Release date - 20112017 SASKATOON, SK and CALGARY, AB - Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan Inc. (PotashCorp) (TSX: POT) (NYSE: POT) and Agrium Inc. Each company's letter of transmittal and election form outlines the necessary documentation and information required to be sent to the depositary for the transaction, AST Trust Company (Canada) (the 'Depositary'), by a registered shareholder in order to receive the shares of the parent entity, Nutrien Ltd., to which they are entitled in exchange for their Agrium or PotashCorp common shares, as applicable, once the transaction is completed and, if eligible, to make an election in respect of their shares. The letters of transmittal and election forms are for use by registered shareholders only. Beneficial shareholders that do not have their common shares of Agrium or PotashCorp registered in their name (rather, such shares are registered in the name of a broker or other intermediary) should contact their broker or other intermediary for instructions and assistance regarding receipt of any shares of Nutrien Ltd. to which they are entitled once the transaction is completed or, if eligible, to make an election in respect of their shares. The letters of transmittal and election forms also provide eligible Canadian residents that are registered Agrium and PotashCorp shareholders with the ability to make an election to have the exchange of their Agrium or PotashCorp shares carried out in such a manner that may allow such shareholders to defer the realization of any accrued capital gain or a capital loss for Canadian federal income tax purposes (without the need to complete any tax election forms). As noted in the joint information circular, shareholders should consult their own tax advisors for advice in respect of the consequences to them of the transaction having regard to their particular circumstances. Any letter of transmittal and election form deposited with the Depositary will be revocable up to the election deadline by written notice or by filing a later-dated letter of transmittal received by the Depositary prior to the election deadline. A letter of transmittal and election form may not be withdrawn by a shareholder after the election deadline. Agrium and PotashCorp will announce the election deadline in a press release disseminated through nationally recognized wire services in Canada and the United States at least six business days prior to such deadline. As previously announced, Agrium and PotashCorp have obtained the necessary shareholder and court approvals required to meet certain conditions to the completion of the transaction, but completion of the transaction remains conditional on the satisfaction of the remaining regulatory and other customary conditions. Agrium and PotashCorp expect to close the transaction by the end of the fourth quarter of 2017. In the event that the transaction is not completed, any share certificates delivered to the Depositary will be returned. About Agrium Agrium Inc. is a major global producer and distributor of agricultural products, services and solutions. Agrium produces nitrogen, potash and phosphate fertilizers, with a combined wholesale nutrient capacity of close to 11 million tonnes and with significant competitive advantages across our product lines. We supply key products and services directly to growers, including crop nutrients, crop protection, seed, as well as agronomic and application services, thereby helping growers to meet the ever growing global demand for food and fiber. title: SSTL to build Canadian satellite constellation
article: The Canadian UrtheCast company has formally placed a contract with UK firm SSTL to build its UrtheDaily Earth observation (EO) constellation. This network of spacecraft, due to launch in 2020, will image the entire global landmass (not including Antarctica) every 24 hours. One of its key uses will be in smart agriculture - taking pictures to help farmers better manage their crops. SSTL is a world leader in manufacturing satellite constellations. It has produced series of spacecraft for other EO interests, such as the RapidEye network now owned by Planet and the DMC-3 operation leased to the Chinese concern 21AT. SSTL is also in the consortium that makes multiple spacecraft for the European Commissions satellite-navigation system, Galileo. The Guildford-based manufacturer has been working on the UrtheDaily concept with UrtheCast for a while. It would see, most probably, eight spacecraft launched into a polar orbit about 600km above the planet. Arranged like a pearl necklace, these satellites would follow each other, crossing the equator at 10:30 local time. They would gather something on the order of 140 million square km of land imagery a day (clouds permitting) at a resolution of about 5m. UrtheCast is a relatively new operator. It started out taking pictures of the Earth from the space station using British-built cameras, and has since acquired the Spanish Deimos satellites to complement its business. It plans also to launch in the 2020s a novel, high-resolution capability that would see eight pairs of optical and radar satellites circling the globe. This concept is called OptiSAR. Flying radar with optical enables pictures to be gathered in all weathers, even when there is cloud. The leading radar satellite would also map the cloud cover so that the trailing optical spacecraft could more efficiently target those regions of the Earths surface that were clearly observable. Weve been working with UrtheCast on OptiSAR for about three or four years now, and on UrtheDaily for about the the last year, year and a half," explained Luis Gomes from SSTL. "There is an identified need in the market for very high-quality imagery at medium resolution, around 5m, for precision agriculture and environmental monitoring. "Wed already been developing a design for this kind of system and then UrtheCast said it was the kind of thing they wanted. "The aim is to have all the satellites built by 2020. Thats a challenge, but its achievable, he told BBC News. SSTL is about to launch a still and video-imaging satellite for the British EO analytics company Earth-i. The spacecraft, dubbed EiX2, will be the first in what is expected to be a large constellation of platforms.

title: United States : Trimble Adds Distributors to its Global Vantage Network for Agriculture
article: Trimble announced today that it has added four new distributors to its Vantage networka global network of independent experts that provide growers, advisors, retailers, co-ops and local OEM dealers with precision agriculture expertise for the entire farm. Vantage Canada West will provide Trimble total farm solutions throughout Alberta and British Columbia. With offices in Utrecht (The Netherlands) and Sint-Truiden (Belgium), Vantage Benelux focuses on Trimble total farm solutions including precision ag services for growers, contractors and crop advisors throughout the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. As the complexity of integrating multiple systems together across a farming operation increases, so does the need for seamless service and support from technicians that have in-depth knowledge in all areas of precision agriculture. Vantage distributors have a proficient understanding of the entire Trimble portfolio, and they specialize in integrating the hardware, software, data and agronomic considerations across mixed fleet farms to create interoperability throughout an operation's precision ag systems. Vantage serves as a farmer's Partner in Precision Agriculture, providing a premier level of technical expertise, including the ability to connect the agronomic recommendations from a farmer's advisor to the precision ag processes needed to optimize productivity. Vantage distributors are committed to providing a hassle-free experience, dedicated customer service, valuable training and reliable in-field support in order to minimize the stress and confusion that is often associated with complex technology solutions.
